10/29/19, 10:11 - Vikas Panditrao - ICE: _code of conduct_ *Don't Be Evil no more, Google removes famous phrase from its policy document*

The old English phrase-- don't be evil-- has been a part of Google's code of conduct for *18 long years*. Google, which is now a subsidiary of Alphabet Inc, was restructured in 2015. However, the phrase stuck through the transition period appearing thrice in the code of conduct, twice in the beginning and once towards the end. But it seems that the search engine giant has silently removed the phrase from its original text.

Interestingly, this change can be noticed in the company's focus area as well. As per Google's code of conduct, earlier, the company aimed at "providing users unbiased access to information, focusing on their needs and giving them the best products and services that we can". However, following a change in the motto, the preface read, "Google Code of Conduct is built around the recognition that everything we do in connection with our work at Google will be, and should be, measured against the highest possible standards of ethical business conduct"-- which marks a clear diversion in the company's policies and practices.

10/30/19, 11:49 - Vikas Panditrao - ICE: *Sharing CBDC REPORT that covers following areas*

1. Three key developments since the 2008 financial crisis have shaped the discourse on CBDCs and the role of private and public institutions in the creation of money.

2. Central banks‚Äô policy objectives regarding digital currencies are many and various. For policy-makers, specifying the use cases in which a CBDC may apply is paramount.

3. Central banks‚Äô policy goals will determine the technology used. Policy-makers would require a retail CBDC to be accessible, secure and operate for all payments transactions.


4. The particular design of a CBDC, such as whether or not it would bear interest, will determine its effectiveness as a monetary policy instrument and whether any financial stability implications may arise.

5. If introduced, central banks expect they
will outsource some CBDC operations to the private sector, such as the distribution of the currency, onboarding of users and customer- facing services.

10/31/19, 10:37 - Vikas Panditrao - ICE: *FIAKS community member says* 

I believe it is on the way commi ssion mechanism works for upi transactions. Commission is paid to the app provider rather than to the credit or debit bank.  Charges are deducted from debiting bank (not the customer), as UPI is free of cost at most banks. So, irrespective of their app being used or not banks are paying charges to NPCI. In case of wallets like PAYTM, people mostly use credit cards to add money rather than using UPI. In this case PAYTM pays for credit card commission. But in case of companies like Google pay, they earn commission without maintaining wallet. Earlier there are cases where a customer will have multiple UPI ids for the same account and will transfer between these  ids, just for getting the cash back.

I remember the days when customers were paying charges for making fund transfers, and, now customers are dissatisfied when they don't pay charges and they get the message "Better luck next time" in Google Pay.

NPCI should think of doing something to this disparity. Most banks are bleeding due to this.

11/4/19, 00:30 - Vikas Business Phone: *FIAKS community thought leader and our Advisory Committee member Shri A P Hota ji provides great guidance on this matter* 

He says NEFT getting 24x7 was necessary from public policy angle. Objective is to make faster payment universally accessible. Though UPI has taken India leagues ahead of other countries, fact remains that *customers of all the banks donot have access to UPI*. Basic remittance facility should be available to all at speed and convenience. UPI demands a technology level of the service providing banks that many small banks have neither the capacity not would regulator permit them in the near future. Basic service should not be the privilege of large banks only - banking license having been granted and customers of all banks having the same basic requirement. It is for this reason that Fed is going for FedNow though the private sector in US has already created 3-4 real time service as private clubs. Congress has directed Fed to do with with a bill having been passed. Our RBI and NPCI are so progressive. 

But NEFT is available to customers of almost all banks through a variety of aggregators. 

NPCI has is nothing to worry. While NPCI will keep enabling more and more banks on UPI, NPCI has developed use cases far richer than the basic funds transfer service which NEFT aims at. UPI volume would keep zooming. 

As on today, it is not clear whether RBI aims at making NEFT real time - meaning beneficiary account being credited real time.  Current practice is the funds transfer message is delivered real time to the beneficiary bank but credit by the beneficiary bank to customer account instantly is discretionary. Mandate is to confirm the position within ( I think one hour). Which means, the beneficiary bank has an window to verify. 

Besides, Settlement takes place every half an hour on a net basis. It is still not clear, how net settle the every half an hour would take place on Saturday and Sunday. Either RTGS timing would have to be reviewed or RBI has to go for a settlement guarantee fund or pooling of funds separately just for settlement during non-RTGS hours. We will have to wait for detailed framework.  Creation of SGF will demand banks forking out some funds. May be RBI itself will create a development fund from its own account to promote digital payments. Small banks will certainly make this demand. 

Who knows, plain vanilla extension of time 24x7 with no other change will take place with nearly 50 half hourly settlements being further netted and settled on Monday morning ( crude way of doing, but possible!). But banks will have to keep monitoring staff 24x7. 

Let us watch. In a fortnight or so, RBI will start consulting banks. 

Let UPI journey go unhindered. Let IPO   Collection through UPI happen. It would be a great Story for SEBI apart from RBI, banks and NPCI. Let us wish NCI- ‚Äúthe Jewel‚Äù described by Nilekani keep shining. 24x7 NEFT on one side and UPI - IMPS combined on the other will the twin engine to push the retail payments in India.

11/19/19, 09:16 - Forum of Industry and Academic Knowledge Sharing: _Passwordless_ *Passwords should become a thing of the past. Here's why*

Passwords were once one of our most trusted security measures, but over the past decade, the average person‚Äôs digital footprint has been exposed to increasing numbers of third parties. Now the average consumer manages over *191 pairs* of usernames and passwords. It is almost guaranteed that people reuse the same passwords or tactics to authenticate across various services.

Most of the recent data breaches stem from stolen passwords. As digital platforms pile up gigabytes of data, including personal information and the credentials we use to get access to their digital services, the cost of attacks for hackers has decreased significantly. *You can now buy login credentials to someone‚Äôs bank or Uber account on the dark web for as little as $7*. Knowledge-based authentication, whether with PINs, passwords, passphrases, or whatever we need to remember, are not only a major headache for users - they cost a lot of money to maintain. Without even looking at the costs of a cyberattack, the mere costs of password management, of time lost by employees typing passwords and chasing the IT department when they fail, can climb up to $70 per incident. And with up to 50% of all help-desk calls being password resets, the costs can mount up quickly.
https://bit.ly/2r7d9yo
11/19/19, 09:20 - +91 90046 19987: https://youtu.be/SHxT9-2knr8
11/19/19, 09:30 - Vikas Business Phone: *FIAKS community CXO bank shared the following update on "what is NPA DIVERGENCE?"* 

Ref -IOB report divergence of NPAs for FY19

Indian Overseas Bank (IOB) revised its net loss for FY19 to Rs. 6,000 crore from Rs. 3,738 crore, as reported earlier. So far, five banks have disclosed divergences in asset recognition for FY19.

_All you wanted to know about...NPA divergence_

Many of us are in the habit of pushing away a hard task for a later date, in the hope that it will become easier with time. That is precisely what banks seem to have been doing with their bad loans, hiding them in the complex jumble of numbers that make up their books of account, in the hope that the bad loans could turn good with passage of time.

But the RBI is not having any of that. It has asked banks to come clean about the true state of affairs. While this is hurting banks‚Äô earnings and the investor sentiment, this clean-up could hopefully help over the long run.

*What is it?*
The RBI in a circular last year on ‚ÄòDisclosure in the Notes to Accounts to the Financial Statements ‚Äì Divergence in Asset Classification and Provisioning‚Äô, had stated that there have been instances of material divergences in banks‚Äô asset classification and provisioning from the RBI norms, thereby leading to the published financial statements not depicting a true and fair view of the financial position.

The RBI had also laid down specific conditions when disclosures have to be made ‚Äî the mandated provisioning by the RBI exceeded 15 per cent of published profit after tax for the period under question or additional gross NPA identified by the RBI exceeded 15 per cent of the published figure.

As if on cue, since the issue of the circular, banks have been disclosing sharp bad loan divergences from their reported numbers for two consecutive fiscals (FY16 and FY17).

For instance, Axis Bank reported gross non-performing assets (GNPAs) in FY16. As assessed by the RBI, the GNPAs were higher ‚Äî implying a sharp divergence. The bank has gone on to report another divergences pertaining to FY17. YES Bank reported a divergence in  FY17.

SBI reported bad loan divergence in FY17.

*Why is it important?*
Over the last two to three years, the RBI has single-mindedly focussed on cleaning up banks‚Äô balance sheets.

First came the asset quality review, or AQR, in 2015, that mostly impacted public sector banks.

A chunk of the slippages emerged from the so-called restructured accounts ‚Äî wherein the original terms and conditions of loans are relaxed to provide a breather to borrowers facing financial stress.

The flushing out of the rot in banks‚Äô books through AQR proved inadequate as banks, continued to witness sharp slippages.

The central bank‚Äôs annual risk-based supervision leading to disclosure of huge divergences by banks, has become another key parameter die-hard investors and analysts need to watch out for.

*Why should I care?*

‚ÄòNPAs‚Äô, ‚ÄòAQR‚Äô, divergence, et al are not just high-flying banking jargon. Each has far-reaching implications on the financial health of your bank.

When a borrower defaults in his payments, banks are required to set aside a portion of their earnings as provisions towards these loans to provide a buffer in case of future losses. A sharp rise in NPAs can hence erode a bank‚Äôs profits.

Sharp divergences spell doom when banks carry insufficient capital to absorb sudden losses on account of increase in bad loan provisioning. Since much of banks‚Äô activities are funded by deposits, and have to be repaid at a future date, it is imperative that a bank carries sufficient amount of capital to remain viable.

*Bottomline*
The next time your bank reports bad loan divergences, sit up and take note.

11/19/19, 17:23 - Forum of Industry and Academic Knowledge Sharing: _Digital Currency_ *A Country May Issue a Digital Currency in 5 Years*

Several countries have already experimented with forms of digital currency. In 2017, Uruguay launched the *e-peso* as a pilot project, making the digital currency available to the public as a complement to cash. The pilot ended in April 2018 and since then, the country's central bank has been considering whether a digital currency can be implemented and what impact it would have on the national monetary system.

The Central Bank of The Bahamas also announced " *Project Sand Dollar* " in March of this year. This program consisted of a CBDC built on blockchain technology that aimed to make the financial system more efficient.

"It remains unclear whether blockchain technology or its analogues are the best route forward for digital currency implementation, and central banks by and large are technology agnostic," say the authors of the OMFIF-IBM report. "Ideally, they will settle on their precise policy objectives and then find the most appropriate technological solution, rather than be wedded to a specific technology beforehand."

11/20/19, 09:39 - Vikas Business Phone: *FIAKS community thought leader and FIAKS award winner shared this article on*
 
*_Why MNCs are changing their India tune_*

If you are someone who has watched multinational firms‚Äô India play in the heady days of the 1990s and 2000s, the current goings-on are a big let-down. Back then, for the globetrotting MNCs India was the last El Dorado, to be conquered and won at all cost. Though China, another big consumer market, also beckoned, it was considered ‚Äútaken‚Äù, by either government-led local firms or other MNC peers.

No wonder most played the Indian market much in the PGA Tour's Together Anything‚Äôs Possible style, their ambition not constrained by money, men or material. The liberalisation and globalisation-led 90s and noughties was a time when western capital markets were infatuated with a strong emerging market play, and fortunes were made or lost on mere the mention of whether the firm was going in or out of India!

Global firms poured money into India as if there was no tomorrow, and often chased losing, thin on strategy ideas and projects that they would have been loath to back in most developed markets. *It was clear that there was a huge error in estimating the true size of the addressable Indian market*, and some correction in expectations did happen in the 2000s and later, but most kept the faith and the purse strings open.

Something has changed dramatically of late. *Though in the past four-five years alone, there have been some flight out of the country by MNCs* ‚Äî such as French retailer *Carrefour closing* down its cash-and-carry business in 2014 or Japanese drugmaker *Daiichi Sankyo exiting* India in 2015 ‚Äî it is not so much a Quit India movement as yet. More like an expectation that India has to start behaving like any other market and stand up on its own and stop depending on the parent‚Äôs largesse. The reasons are myriad. For some, it is the global strategy at play, but for most it is India-specific issues like regulatory overhang, underperformance of the market or the inability to compete in perhaps of the world‚Äôs most complex market.

After pouring over Rs 1 trillion in the last decade or so, British telco Vodafone announced last week that it has finally closed the funding spigot to its gasping Indian subsidiary, and is ready to face... well... even exit from the country if it comes to that. One of the earliest MNC carmakers into India, American *Ford Motors has agreed to take a junior role in a partnership with local automaker Mahindra & Mahindra* for its struggling operations in India. Why, even General Motors is learned to be looking for buyers for its only remaining factory in India in Pune.
 
Though not as dramatic as a retreat from India, there is clear change of tack among many others across sectors. Time was when American beverages major *Coca-Cola* was gobbling bottlers in India, and writing down losses it had run up to fuel its aggressive take-markets-at-all-cost strategy. Now, the firm is reportedly hawking those bottling plants to its franchise bottlers in order to generate cash.

Japanese investor SoftBank, after pouring in almost $10 billion in Indian startups, including nine unicorns, is demanding all new funding to be linked to time-bound public exits or the chance to sell stake to any willing buyer. Singed by huge losses run up by its Vision Fund globally due to unprofitable bets on WeWork and Uber, SoftBank, according to venture capital tracing firm Tracxn, has not put even a single dollar in new investment in India this year! And after a bitter separation with its partner for half of the country, McDonald‚Äôs has now reportedly put stricter rules for prospective new partners with no leeway to take the operations public and to hypothecate the operating company‚Äôs shares to the parent.

11/24/19, 16:29 - Vikas Business Phone: *FIAKS Community Thought leader (CXO banker) shared this interesting story with LUCK as theme.*

One night I was invited to a dinner, where I sat next to the wife of a big shot at a giant Wall Street investment bank, called Salomon Brothers. She more or less forced her husband to give me a job. I knew next to nothing about Salomon Brothers. But Salomon Brothers happened to be where Wall Street was being reinvented‚Äî into the place we have all come to know and love. When I got there I was assigned, almost arbitrarily, to the very best job in which to observe the growing madness: they turned me into the house expert on derivatives. A year and a half later Salomon Brothers was handing me a check for hundreds of thousands of dollars to give advice about derivatives to professional investors.

The book I wrote was called Liar‚Äôs Poker. It sold a million copies. I was 28 years old. I had a career, a little fame, a small fortune and a new life narrative. All of a sudden people were telling me I was born to be a writer. This was absurd. Even I could see there was another, truer narrative, with luck as its theme. *What were the odds of being seated at that dinner next to that Salomon Brothers lady? Of landing inside the best Wall Street firm from which to write the story of an age? Of landing in the seat with the best view of the business? Of having parents who didn‚Äôt disinherit me but instead sighed and said ‚Äúdo it if you must?‚Äù Of having had that sense of must kindled inside me by a professor of art history at Princeton? Of having been let into Princeton in the first place?*
- Michael Lewis
11/24/19, 16:50 - Vikas Business Phone: <Media omitted>
11/24/19, 18:02 - Vikas Business Phone: *Intellectial Speak-FIAKS community thought leaders opine on Salomon Brothers story on Luck*

*View 1-  Founder Fintech*

Those were mad times at Wall Street with John Gutfreund (Salomon) and Milken (Drexel) at the helm. It is a superb book. His other books like Moneyball and even the recent The Big Short all very good.

*View -  2 CXO  Private Banker*

This is called Mathew Effect.  This theory explains how privileged end up getting more privileges and under privileged lose whatever little privileges they may have had . 

The term has biblical links.. 
  'For unto every one that have shall be given, and he shall have abundance; but him that have not shall be taken, even that which he have.' Matthew 25:29

*View 3 - CXO PSU Banker*

Not *All* but luck is very important. *Almost every* successful person (those who amass great fortune) is perhaps extremely talented and hardworking but *NOT every* extremely talented and hardworking is successful! So, as they say talent and hardwork are *necessary but not sufficient* for success. *Chance events /luck play a much larger role in important life outcomes (sometimes difference between life and death) than most people imagine.*

11/25/19, 13:39 - Vikas Business Phone: *FIAKS community member on today‚Äôs  news of Digital payments venture Paytm has scooped $1 billion (Rs 7,170 crore) in a fresh round of funding led by American investment firm T Rowe Price besides existing investors Ant Financial (formerly Alipay) and SoftBank, the firm said.The deal was struck at a valuation of $16 billion (Rs 1.14 trillion). He shared an extract of report on *India Fintech: That was circulated after meeting  the top Indian fintech founders - key takeaways and implications for financial services*

1. *Paytm's lead, UPI disruption and banking play*:
Before we met Paytm, there were multiple questions, flagged to us by investors and industry participants:
1. Impact of UPI on Paytm's mobile wallet business
2. Paytm payment bank's limited traction and run-ins with the regulator
3. Paytm's monetization strategy with lack of ability to lend
We met the leadership at Paytm and also collected feedback from participants across the trip. We came back with a sense, that *a lot of capabilities Paytm has built under the hood is unappreciated by banks and its more direct fintech competitors*. Paytm's consumer engagement continues with its higher contribution lifestyle business (travel, entertainment, food, content, games, deals, advertisement). On the merchant side, UPI QR acceptance has increased but Paytm has built an integrated merchant business (across wallets, QR, UPI and now card acceptance). Paytm has feet on the ground on merchant management, which many of its UPI competitors are yet to build. Paytm also has a merchant relationship management software stack with invoice, reconciliation CRM, rewards & merchant lending which further builds merchant hooks. Further, UPI has enabled Paytm to save payment gateway fees in costs.
On the payments bank, we got a distinct sense that the management team has matured in its regulatory understanding and regulatory process management. The Paytm bank has a more traditional CEO now (from the banking industry) with ability to maintain strong in-house processes while the product team churns out a high quality banking product (the new banking app in beta looks slick) versus recent outages of mobile banking apps at private banks.
On acquiring, Paytm started with its closed loop integrated wallet check out via QR at merchants. Post UPI, Paytm has integrated the UPI QR ability (single QR code) across its merchant base. Paytm further has expanded its merchant acquiring platform with card acceptance capability (~1,20,000 terminals). Given, the co-existence of cards, UPI QR and wallets, Paytm is building a neutral merchant acceptance platform. Paytm is also focused on ensuring higher activation levels at merchants. Paytm has a strong 'feet on street' force combined with active centralized monitoring to ensure high activation rate at merchants.
On the lending side, Paytm doesn't look averse to take the bold step to lending from its own balance sheet after realization that the bank partnership model has its challenges.

11/29/19, 09:45 - Vikas Business Phone: *FIAKS community member on eSIM*

*WHAT IS eSIM?*
An eSIM is an electronic SIM card also known as embedded SIM. As the name suggests, it will replace the physical, plastic SIM card

With such an embedded standard, the idea is that you can switch to a new operator without having to insert a specific SIM card. It‚Äôs all done through software.
That is it enables users to change operator remotely, straight from their phone, without having to acquire a new SIM card.

It also allows people to store multiple profiles on a single device, effectively having two or more numbers, and switch between them at ease

eSIM has the ability to use and store multiple profiles. If you travel, for example, getting access to a new country's mobile provider won't require tracking down and swapping out SIM cards.

*QUESTION: Does UPI Support eSIM?*
_Community member says_ 
Esim is just like any other sim except for the part no physical presence on the phone. So when you try to enable the phone to UPI payments, it will work like regular phone.

Plus eSim is actually not so actively used here.. bcoz only 2 telcos give it.. Jio and Airtel.. both only for Postpaid connect...

Currently it‚Äôs less than 1% of total smartphone...
11/29/19, 09:54 - Vikas Business Phone: *FIAKS community expert shares view on eSIM* he further adds 

eSim has no impact on UPI. eSim is a physical replacement of a SIM through software on eSim supported handsets. It is a great feature especially for inernational Roaming subscriber. Keep your home country on eSim and buy physical Sim abraod at Airport. Data is very cost effective this way.

12/5/19, 09:05 - Forum of Industry and Academic Knowledge Sharing: _Application Development_ : *Why are software development houses switching to no-code?*

A no-code platform requires no knowledge of coding from a developer. Instead of requiring traditional programming language skills, no-code platforms enable a developer to build via what is known as visual modelling. You define the logic of your application, then select components for the build (‚Äúblocks‚Äù) from a library, dragging and dropping them into an on-screen workflow. No-code platforms also allow for the smooth integration of newly built applications ‚Äì existing web services and application programming interfaces (APIs) ‚Äì into an organisation‚Äôs enterprise resource planning (ERP) architecture.

No-code platforms for application development offer the advantages of speed and ease of use, and help firms escape developer skills shortages.

Although no one is saying that coding is dead or that programmers are going to be out of a job soon, there is no denying that the current demand for software far exceeds the supply of coders and that many traditional ways of building applications are complex and time-consuming.

*_View 11-  CXO MNC banker_*

12/5/19, 13:59 - Forum of Industry and Academic Knowledge Sharing: _FIAKS Aggregation of Latest Circular(FALC) 013_

*RBI issues circular : Statement on Development and Regulatory Policies*

Key points to consider:

7. Review of NBFC-P2P Directions- Aggregate Lender Limit and escrow accounts
The Reserve Bank had issued directions for Non-Banking Financial Company-Peer to Peer 
Lending platform (NBFC-P2P) on October 4, 2017. At present, the aggregate limits for both 
borrowers and lenders across all P2P platforms stand at ‚Çπ10 lakh, whereas exposure of a 
single lender to a single borrower is capped at ‚Çπ50,000 across all NBFC-P2P platforms. A 
review of the functioning of the lending platforms and lending limit was carried out and it has 
been decided that in order to give the next push to the lending platforms, the aggregate 
exposure of a lender to all borrowers at any point of time, across all P2P platforms, shall be 
subject to a cap of ‚Çπ50 lakh. Further, it is also proposed to do away with the current 
requirement of escrow accounts to be operated by bank promoted trustee for transfer of funds 
having to be necessarily opened with the concerned bank. This will help provide more 
flexibility in operations. Necessary instructions in this regard will be issued shortly.


10. New Pre-Paid Payment Instruments (PPI)
Prepaid Payment Instruments (PPIs) have been playing an important role in promoting digital 
payments. To further facilitate its usage, it is proposed to introduce a new type of PPI which 
can be used only for purchase of goods and services up to a limit of ‚Çπ10,000. The loading / 
reloading of such PPI will be only from a bank account and used for making only digital 
payments such as bill payments, merchant payments, etc. Such PPIs can be issued on the basis 
of essential minimum details sourced from the customer. Instructions in this regard will be 
issued by December 31, 2019.

*Transforming Infrastructure: Frameworks for bringing the fourth industrial revolution to infrastructure*
¬†The technological advances of the Fourth Industrial Revolution have fundamentally altered society in ways both seen and unseen. This digital transformation has changed how people live and work, and everything inbetween. One area of daily life, however, seems to be largely missing out on this revolution: infrastructure. It remains one of the least digitally transformed sectors of the economy. The report addresses the following questions-¬†
 1) *How can technological disruption in the white space of infrastructure be encouraged?* 
2) *How does the public sector drive innovation in technology by creating frameworks that encourage exchange while protecting intellectual property?*

4) *How can viable commercial models be created via catalytic policy and regulatory frameworks?*

12/10/19, 09:41 - Fintech Easy2lend Riaz Maniyar NnR: <Media omitted>
12/10/19, 09:53 - Fintech Shirisha ghosh Torit NnR: I have live example. 
Posted one Ad in OLX. Scammer calls me and burgains like normal people. Then asks to courier the phone and Payment via Google Pay. 
I said okay. He then sends me QR code of Freecharge and asks me to scan. I understood the fraud and continued. I scanned the QR it says the Amount and the message written below it "Amount is transferred to your Account". Then the scammer asks me to continue and "Check my Balance" putting the PIN. I changed the bank account where I have no funds and continue and Transaction failed due to Insufficient Funds. Then the scammer again sends QR codes for less values and saying different technical terms like merchant account, mdr, payment gateway etc etc. I then scold him and cut the call.

*View 5* CXO Payment professional

Its very simple, news papers and customers are not reporting the entire facts, nothing can be derived from partial and sensational stories. Else we  all know by now, the familiar route of "download an app" " click on a link" and gullible customers filling all details. Bottomline, till date all scams have been phishing requests to make the customer reveal the banking details.

*Industry evangelist on FIAKS platform shares an extract from recent article on ‚ÄúQR CODE SCAM‚Äù*

*How does this scam work?*

Basically, it does the same as when you would enter your login credentials on a banking phish site. The scammers used social engineering to con victims into allowing them to scan the QR code on their own phone. By doing so, the victims provided the scammers with the login credentials to their banking environment.

With those in hand, it‚Äôs easy for the threat actors to make some payments on your behalf‚Äîinto accounts under their control, obviously. It is likely that they used money mules to convert those payments into cash they could then spend freely without raising suspicion.

*Other QR scams*

Besides the fake banking environment scam, there have been reports of QR codes that were rigged to download malware onto the victim‚Äôs device. Also, criminals have been known to replace public and unguarded QR codes with their own so that payments would flow into their pockets.

For example, in China where bike-sharing is immensely popular and you pay in advance to unlock the bike, it can be profitable for criminals to replace the QR codes on a large number of bikes with some of their own. This could bring in a lot of (small) payments into the threat actor‚Äôs account, and many potential bike renters would shrug it off when the bike fails to unlock and move on to the next one to try their luck.

12/11/19, 12:01 - Forum of Industry and Academic Knowledge Sharing: _Cookies_ *Why every website wants you to accept its cookies*

To back up a little bit, cookies are pieces of information saved about you when you‚Äôre online, and they track you as you browse. So say you go to a weather website and put in your zip code to look up what‚Äôs happening in your area; the next time you visit the same site, it will remember your zip code because of cookies. There are first-party cookies that are placed by the site you visit, and then there are third-party cookies, such as those placed by advertisers to see what you‚Äôre interested in and in turn serve you ads ‚Äî even when you leave the original site you visited. (This is how ads follow you around the internet.)

The proliferation of such alerts was largely triggered by two different regulations in Europe: the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), a sweeping data privacy law enacted in the European Union in May 2018; and the ePrivacy Directive, which was first passed in 2002 and then updated in 2009. They, and the cookie alerts that resulted, have plenty of good intentions. But they‚Äôre ineffectual.

12/11/19, 21:23 - Vikas Business Phone: *FIAKS community CXO Banker who part of leadership team of large private sector shared this update on amendments in the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code, 2016*

The Union Cabinet chaired by the Prime Minister Shri Narendra Modi today approved the proposal to make amendments in the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code, 2016 (code), through the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code (Second Amendment) Bill, 2019.  The amendments aim to remove certain difficulties being faced during insolvency resolution process to realise the objects of the code and to further ease doing of business.

*Details of the Proposal*
          The Amendment Bill seeks to amend sections 5(12), 5(15), 7, 11, 14, 16(1), 21(2), 23(1), 29A, 227, 239, 240 and insert new section 32A in the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code, 2016 (Code). 

*Impact*
Amendments to the Code to remove bottlenecks, streamline the CIRP and protection of last mile funding will boost investment in financially distressed sectors.
Additional thresholds introduced for Financial Creditors represented by an authorized representative due to large numbers in order to prevent frivolous triggering of Corporate Insolvency Resolution Process (CIRP).
Ensuring that the substratum of the business of corporate debtor is not lost, and it can continue as a going concern by clarifying that the licenses, permits, concessions, clearances etc. cannot be terminated or suspended or not renewed during the moratorium period.
Ring-fencing corporate debtor resolved under the IBC in favour of a successful resolution applicant from criminal proceedings against offences committed by previous management/promoters.

Customer accounts will be opened to third-party access in stages. In the first stage, access will be provided to information on balances and transactions in the customer's current account, within one year from the publication of this directive. The third stage will include access to additional customer information on the customer's credit and loans, on the customer's deposits and savings, and on the customer's securities portfolio, all within two years from the publication of this directive.

12/12/19, 09:57 - Vikas Business Phone: *Intellectual Speaks:FIAKS Community Experts raised major concern On OPEN BANKING* 

*View 4*
One of the main challenges facing open banking is *security*. The majority of companies that are championing open banking are small FinTech companies, not tech giants like Apple and Google, and a lack of homogenous technical standards, such as certain security requirements, combined with complex internal technology systems may make the process susceptible to corruption and fraudulent activity

Another concern about open banking is liability, as inserting *third-party providers* into the banking process *increases the risk of scammers gaining access to customer information and their finances*. Under open banking, consumers should have any losses replenished by their bank unless there is reason to suspect fraud or negligence, but with both banks and FinTechs alike facing increased security threats, without proper legal clarification it‚Äôs inevitable that providers will try and blame a third party.
12/12/19, 10:22 - Vikas Business Phone: *Intellectual Speaks:FIAKS Community Experts CXO banker shared anonymously on OPEN BANKING CONCERNS*

*Views 17*

 Imagine a customer who banks with a financial institution that has an open banking relationship with a *third party offering* other services. As a result, the third party has access to some customer details. If the third party experiences a breach, the customer‚Äôs details could become available to *criminal organizations*.

That possibility illustrates some of the biggest concerns with open banking: *privacy breaches, data security, cybercrime and fraud*. The financial services industry is already a significant target of fraud and hacking attempts.

Open banking has the potential to magnify the impact of breach and cybersecurity incidents when they happen, which could mean reputational risk and erosion of customer trust for the banks


*Question* Can leadership team of bank  be made accountable for blunders that happen on account of beaches due to open banking.

Decisions makers walking away by  saying nothing is  100% safe and putting customer at risk is just *NOT* acceptable.

12/13/19, 14:05 - Vikas Business Phone: *The Union Cabinet has approved overhaul of Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code, 2016 through Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code (Second Amendment) Bill, 2019.* Important point to be known About it 


*Point 1*. The latest changes to the IBC ring-fence the successful bidders of stressed assets from the risk of criminal proceedings against offences committed by previous management and promoters, according to an official statement. 

*Point 2* . In other words, successful bidders will be provided more immunity against any risk of criminal proceedings for offences committed by previous promoters of companies concerned. 

*Point 3*. The bill also proposes a threshold for financial creditors to prevent frivolous triggering of corporate insolvency. In other words, this will ensure that bankruptcy is not invoked for small amounts. 

*Point 4*. The amendments are aimed at providing more protection to bidders participating in the recovery proceedings and in turn boosting investor confidence in the country's financial system.

*Point 5* The provisions allow the corporate debtors to continue as a going concern by clarifying that the licenses, permits, concessions and clearances cannot be terminated or suspended during the moratorium period.

*Point 6* "Approval by the cabinet to provide immunity to successful bidders under IBC is a great boost to IBC," said Sapan Gupta, partner and national head of banking and finance at law firm Shardul Amarchand Mangaldas."This is a positive and timely step and will increase confidence among prospective buyers of stressed assets."

*point 7*. The government has in the past few months announced a series of steps to restore the health of the country's financial sector to achieve its goal of making India a $5-trillion economy. The country's economy expanded 5 per cent in the quarter ended September 30, marking the lowest pace of growth in more than six years. 

*Point 8* . In a separate development, the cabinet approved Partial Credit Guarantee Scheme for purchase of high-rated pooled assets from financially sound non-banking financial companies (NBFCs) - also known as shadow banks - by state-run banks.

*Point 9* Easier lending rules are aimed at enabling NBFCs to get better access to funds. NBFCs have been key drivers of lending growth in India, with their consolidated balance sheet worth Rs 28.8 lakh crore ($400 billion) in 2018-19, according to RBI data. 

*Point 10* The Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code replaces laws such as the Sick Industrial Companies Act (SICA Act) and the Securitisation and Reconstruction of Financial Assets and Enforcement of Securities Interest Act (SARFAESI Act), shifting the control of recovery process to creditors from borrowers.

12/18/19, 23:23 - Vikas Business Phone: *FIAKS community member on BANK OF BARODA underreported bad loans by ‚Çπ5,250 crore in FY19: RBI report*



*View 23* _Advisor PSU bank and former Chief General Manager says_


There are a number of criteria for identifying NPAs which are subjective in nature. For example, as per RBI guidelines, accounts showing "intrinsic weakness" should be deemed as NPAs..
Quite often, it's easier for RBI inspectors to flag an account as intrinsically weak because they come after the balance sheet date, when the weaknesses are more evident than it was when the balance sheet was prepared by the Bank a few months ago.
Normally, no bank management would classify an "intrinsically weak" account as NPA, if the recovery record is in order when the balance sheet is prepared.
The same account may be having overdues of over 90 days when the RBI inspectors walk in to check the books after few months.
This is a common cause for divergences.

 *Financial Services Technology 2020 and Beyond: Embracing disruption*

Financial institutions have a lot on their plate: emerging competitors,

‚ñ™The "buy now, pay later" model lends itself to the instant gratification that people ‚Äî particularly younger consumers ‚Äî want. So, younger consumers have become the primary audience for many of these services, driving much of their volume.

12/23/19, 11:21 - Forum of Industry and Academic Knowledge Sharing: _Open Banking_: *Open banking reforms delayed as security tests drag on*

The consumer watchdog will spend more time ensuring a new financial data-sharing regime is resilient against cyber security threats, after technical hiccups delayed the launch of open banking by six months.

The change will hold back the plans of neobanks keen to entice big bank customers who are willing to share their data, but the ACCC said the rollout had proven more complex than it had expected and that trust in the system was vital.

Open banking is a policy that will allow bank customers to securely share financial data about them held by the bank with a competitor, such as a fintech firm.

ACCC Commissioner Sarah Court said that after various technical defects were detected, it would not have been responsible to roll out open banking in February, which had always been a tight time frame.

The National Minorities Development & Finance Corporation (NMDFC) was incorporated on 30th September 1994, as a company not for profit, under Section 25 of the Companies Act 1956 (now Section-8 of Companies Act,2013). It is a National Level Apex Body for the benefit of Minorities as defined under the National Commission for  Minorities Act 1992.

The prime mandate of NMDFC is to provide *concessional finance to the Minorities for self employment/ income generation activities*. As per the National Commission  for Minorities Act, 1992, *the notified Minorities are Muslims, Christians, Sikhs, Buddhists & Parsis*. Subsequently, Jain  community was also added into the list of notified Minority Communities in January 2014. Under NMDFC programe, preference is given to Artisans & Women.

12/23/19, 19:09 - Vikas Business Phone: *FIAKS community responses on Religion as KYC data point* by FIAKS award winner. He says 

Firstly we should  accept that religion is an integral part of most Indians' lives.  It is on your face everyday right from the morning Aartis, aazan calls, good morning greetings in WhatsApp and even Bhajan groups in local trains .  So to hide behind Western standards of propriety and exclude this critical data point from Bank records is foolish. Like any non core data  the individual concerned should have the option not to provide the data if he so chooses,  but *Banks asking for it per se should not be frowned upon*.  In West a vast majority of people consider themselves as non religious  but in India hardly 1% will fall in this group. Discrimination basis religion can happen even if I don't provide it explicitly , in most cases it will be self evident from the name itself! At an aggregate level this data can be valuable.  Like how many Jan Dhan accounts are there for a community and what balances they enjoy and their saving and spend habits.  It can help the bank decide at what time bank should pitch for a personal loan  to a customer - for Diwali or ramadan; Should we offer interest bearing products or profit sharing products etc.  Of course there has to be strict rules to ensure the information is not used to discriminate or favour any Group,  *but the idea that we can prevent discrimination by suppressing information is flawed.*

He says

 That's why the risk is handled using liability shift. In a payment cycle whoever does not have EMV capability, (acquirer or issuer), bears the liability, if there is a charge back

Many banks have resorted to stopping magstripe transactions even as fallback, apprehending liability shift, if transaction is fraudulent.

In India, the liability shift has already started as the deadline for ATM acquiring was already over. Hence many issuing banks do not allow magstripe transaction for their customers (as fall back) apprehending liability shift. ATM EMV acquiring

12/30/19, 09:13 - Forum of Industry and Academic Knowledge Sharing: _Artificial intelligence_ *AI is helping us talk to animals*

AI has helped us decode ancient languages, and now researchers are turning the same technique to help understand our pets

Our AI-enhanced abilities to decode languages have reached a point where they could start to parse languages not spoken by anyone alive. Recently, researchers from MIT and Google applied these abilities to ancient scripts ‚Äì Linear B and Ugaritic (a precursor of Hebrew) ‚Äì with reasonable success (no luck so far with the older, and as-yet undeciphered Linear A).

First, word-to-word relations for a specific language are mapped, using vast databases of text. The system searches texts to see how often each word appears next to every other word. This pattern of appearances is a unique signature that defines the word in a multidimensional parameter space. Researchers estimate that languages ‚Äì all languages ‚Äì can be best described as having 600 independent dimensions of relationships, where each word-word relationship can be seen as a vector in this space. This vector acts as a powerful constraint on how the word can appear in any translation the machine comes up with.

12/31/19, 14:00 - Vikas Business Phone: *FIAKS Community thought leader give thumbs up üëçto this move by the Government*

This is a directive to ensure Rupay Debit Card & UPI are Defacto, while other Payment Methods are optional, in case of any Business, that does >50 Crore turnover.

While this is like paving Red Carpet to UPI & Rupay over other Payment Methods, *this is still not bad, as Government didnot force Merchants to not offer payment methods.*

I remember Microsoft, who led Web Browser Market with it's own Internet Explorer Browser. People used it alot, and Netscape, fought a War that it cannot win, since it cannot replace IE, as long as Microsoft backed it.

what Happened?

Netscape created Mozilla Foundation and Firefox is Born.

If and when Rupay/UPI become monopolies without Value in the Service, we will surely see Mozilla Firefox kind of Collaborative Effort.

But by observing the way it is happening, I donot foresee such situation anywhere in near future...., unless and otherwise, different developments happen in NPCI/RBI/Government.

Note: While I always Expect Government to play the role of Facilitator, I also Expect it to have one of the Contender, as Public Limited Company of the Government, so, possibilities of Collusion and Market Monopoly can be prevented, while Government can rescue Markets from such scenarios.

The Market is HUGE, as long as Government DONOT Prevent Other Payment Methods, I feel, it is good to go, and India is vast for many to come and serve the last mile.
12/31/19, 14:18 - Vikas Business Phone: *FIAKS Community leader on PATENT ON POS* 

He says 
the patent in a POS terminal was a "jugaad" solution in my opinion. the ideal QR code solution should be a dynamic QR code, placed clearly visible to the customer and easily scannable by a customer mobile application. The world over, QR codes are handled on a dedicated terminal / screen, conveniently placed for the customer to view, scan and transact. Getting the QR on a POS terminal and then presenting it to the customer to scan and transact is not the best / optimal solution.

1/10/20, 00:14 - Vikas Business Phone: *FIAKS community member master KYC circular* he adds

RBI has just released a new Video KYC regulation that applies to *all regulated entities (not just banks)*. This means there is no longer any need for physical presence to onboard new users. Here are the details -
1. The video capture must be triggered from the regulated entity's domain (presumably to prevent phishing). *So google duo or facetime CANNOT be used*
2. The *user must be based based in India* (as demonstrated by the geotag collected during the session)
3. The session requires both the user and an employee of the regulated entity to be present simultaneously
4. The *user must present PAN card AND complete his eKYC (relevant for banks) OR provide his Aadhaar XML*. The Aadhaar *XML cannot be more than 3 days old*. Most users today find it difficult to provide an XML file. Also if the XML is old they will have fetch it again. The journey can be really cumbersome and complicated
5. The circular actually encourages AI based facematch, although it places the *accountability for client due diligence squarely with the regulated entity*.

The annual report discovered global parcel volume reached 87 billion in 2018, up from 74bn parcels in 2017 and the highest since the Index began. Despite unprecedented global trade uncertainty, the report forecasts this figure will more than double within the next six years and reach 200 billion parcels by 2025.

The Pitney Bowes Parcel Shipping Index measures both volume and spend for B2B, B2C, C2B and consumer consigned shipments with weight up to 31.5 kg (70 lbs.) in 13 major markets, representing 3.7 billion people.

*Key findings include:*

- China‚Äôs parcel industry volumes achieved CAGR of 41 percent from 2013-2018. Volume grew 26 percent year-over-year although this growth has declined from the 48-61 percent growth seen from 2012-16

- United States ranks highest in the Index for parcel shipping revenue at $119bn.

- Brazil sees the second highest year-over-year growth rate in the Index with a 25 percent increase in year-over-year parcel volume from 2017-18

- India is experiencing CAGR of 25% in parcel volume 2013-18 and year-over-year growth of 21 percent

 *The impact of emerging ecommerce markets such as Brazil and India is strongly evident in the figures.* Brazil‚Äôs year-over-year percentage growth in parcel volume reached 25 percent in 2018 ‚Äì second only to China - as 738m parcels were shipped. This growth comes despite the economic slowdown in Brazil, as ecommerce and logistics partnerships help shift the market.

India also experienced high growth in parcel volumes in 2018, up *21 percent year-over-year to 2.5bn*, and revenues achieving CAGR of 20 percent, boosted by rapid growth in its ecommerce market, higher levels of disposable income and increased internet penetration.

1/13/20, 11:20 - Forum of Industry and Academic Knowledge Sharing: _Data:_ *How Is Data Being Used In The Insurance Industry?*

Today, data can be pulled from almost every aspect of our lives. Technology is implemented into everything we do, from our workouts to the food we buy to how fast we drive our cars. Insurance underwriters have mass amounts of data at their fingertips, which plays a huge role in the underwriting process, and most insurance programs will try to accelerate the process by pulling from key databases. Underwriters are looking at public data such as MIB, motor vehicle records, prescription and drugs records, health records, among other sources, to determine policies. Of course, all of this data complies with the Fair Credit Reporting Act.

Recently, we‚Äôre seeing companies begin to use implicit data available to determine customer risk and mortality. With devices such as Fitbits or Apple Watches, companies and underwriters have access to a wealth of fitness and health data they can analyze in the underwriting process. In the future, there‚Äôs a scenario where someone may have a higher premium based on poor health records or weight, but is still able to lower their premiums by improving their wellness with activities tracked by data from their fitness wearable.

1/13/20, 13:28 - Vikas Business Phone: *What is Juice Jacking?*

In simple words, Juice Jacking is an *attack carried out by hackers through a USB charging cable*. When a user plugs in the charging cable in his mobile‚Äôs charging port, and connects it to any of the rigged charging stations installed at public spaces such as airports, train stations, hotels, cafes etc ‚Äì it gives a back-door entry to hackers into the compromised device. The charging port which is also used for data transfer over the USB, is pointed as the main cause of concern over here. Installing malware, cleaning user data, asking ransom in exchange for access to personal data on the phone, personal and financial account hijacking are just some of the many nefarious things that a hacker can do with this unrestricted access.

1/15/20, 23:45 - Vikas Business Phone: *FIAKS Community responses on why not enhance security to UPI As well like cards* here are few views rest will be in bespoke reports 

*View 24*
UPI fraud is due to negligence if customer and collect/receive money option. The architecture is super secured as on date.

*View 12*
Ha ! UPI already has its share of Collect request frauds already. Just that registration process is not linked with Card CNP status as this check will make the process more tedious and registration failure will go up
IMO, Providing Controls to customer on txn limits, enable/ disable on diff txn types is a good move.

*View 14*
But mandatory opt-in for CNP, contactless even for domestic txn is a step back considering the need to push digital txns. Banks anyway have responsibility to put risk bass control mechanism on all txns

*View 15*
This was brought specifically to control the vishing, that rampantly happened in wallets and UPI. Pressure from Govt. Came to know that finance minister's office was flooded with fraudulent transaction related complaints, especially the recent PAYTM frauds.

*View 22*
Let‚Äôs remember that security and convenience never speak to each other.  Whenever we introduce new security measure, the first thing in our minds should be how would a layman approach this!
When the big card frauds happened a few years back, we realised how vulnerable a customer is, to the vagaries of the system. As a result, We introduced a unique on/off toggle for all digital debits in a customers account. I strongly believe that putting a limit only on card alone may be insufficient as we a country have a boutique of payment options. What‚Äôs also risky, is that we provide the convenience for reset of a forgot credential in one channel, say ATM PIN using netbanking or mobile.  In the ground, it‚Äôs all about how effective is your messaging...

1/20/20, 11:16 - Forum of Industry and Academic Knowledge Sharing: _FIAKS bespoke_ : *Are Bank deposits Safe In Today's Era*

If depositors are allowed to buy deposit insurance from outside companies to protect themselves, which only means that depositors will shift the risk from one financial entity (bank) to another financial entity (insurer). Most likely if a big bank fails it will take down the insurer also.

If a loan is covered by insurance in case of a person‚Äôs demise, why not his deposit be covered by insurance in case of demise of the institution!
http://bit.ly/38hfGXd

*Views* - _Executive Director MNC bank_
This needs to be tested. So far RBI has stepped in to take care of the depositors. Furthermore there are no firm indications that RBI will not do the same again

*View* -  _Fintech Founder_ 
In this case, Insurance Companies need to have a Forum that helps them know and analyze Bank's happenings, and have their say, when malicious events happen in Bank and that donot take down the insurance company when bank goes down.

1/27/20, 13:31 - Forum of Industry and Academic Knowledge Sharing: _Facial Recognition:_ *How Facial Recognition Works*

The controversial and nearly ever-present technology that could replace the fingerprint. 

The sudden explosion of facial recognition into public consciousness can make it seem a force as unstoppable as the weather, but the technology didn‚Äôt come out of nowhere. The first facial-recognition technology was arguably created by the French police officer Alphonse Bertillon more than a century ago. In the late 1800s, Bertillon devised a method for identifying criminals based on their physical features. The index cards assigned to each person included 11 physical measurements plus standardized photographic portraits and a ‚Äúverbal portrait.‚Äù This early biometric system allowed the body to be abstracted into information; it was ‚Äúa transformation of the body‚Äôs signs into text,‚Äù wrote the late critic Allan Sekula. In theory, this text made the process of identifying people less prone to human error. Bertillon‚Äôs system became widely used in France and soon spread to the United States, where it gained brief popularity until it was replaced by a much quicker and more reliable ruler: fingerprinting.

Under article 87 regulation (EU) 2016/679 General Data Protection Regulation GDPR, member states may define the specific conditions for the processing of a national identification number or any other identifier of general application. As discussed below, France has made an interesting application of this rule regarding, in particular, the social security number. 

In France, the number referred to as ‚ÄúNIR‚Äù (which stands for ‚Äúnum√©ro d‚Äôindentificaiton nationale‚Äù or ‚Äúsocial security number‚Äù) has always required particular care and protection as it is the only unique identifier for each individual and is tied to personal data including gender and date of birth. The NIR may be used for identity theft while at the same time, be used as an error-free ID reference, for the purpose of combining data from various sources at a very large scale.

Therefore, France has provided for specific rules in relation to its use.

1/30/20, 11:29 - Forum of Industry and Academic Knowledge Sharing: _Insurance_: *Beware Medicare‚Äôs Part B Premium Penalty And Surcharge Traps*

In determining if you need to permanently pay a Medicare Part B penalty, Medicare counts all the months between age 65 and the month you first enroll in Part B even if you, like Sue, had a series of jobs with a largish employer with no gap between jobs extending beyond 8 months. Instead of being exempt from the penalty because she was always in a special enrollment periods between jobs, Sue was hit with a 20 percent lifetime Medicare Part B premium penalty! This is calculated based off of Medicare's base premium, which is $144.60 for 2020. Hence, Sue's penalty, this year, is $28.90 (.20 x $144.60) per month or $347.04 over the year. Moreover, since the base premium can rise, through time, faster than the rate of inflation, Sue's real penalty (her penalty measured in today's dollars) may be higher, indeed a lot higher, down the road.

1/31/20, 12:03 - Vikas Business Phone: _FIAKS Vdo 35_ *flash-charging technology* 

ABB‚Äôs 20-second flash-charging technology for  electric buses.

A TOSA bus looks in many ways similar to the various types of articulated buses used around the world. People may notice only that the electric TOSA bus is nearly silent, compared with the diesel buses prevalant in many urban areas. And of course the e-buses do not spew exhaust clouds when pulling away from the bus stop and accelerating into traffic.

The big difference, though, occurs when the TOSA bus reaches a stop equipped with a flash charging system. As soon as the bus arrives, a laser-controlled arm on the roof connects in less than a second to an overhead receptacle built into the bus shelter. The connection provides a high-power charge ‚Äì using a feed of up to 600 kilowatts. The boost recharges the battery enough to let the bus continue on its way.

*THE ASEAN FINTECH ECOSYSTEM BENCHMARKING STUDY*
_This report is jointly produced by the Cambridge Center for Alternative Finance at Cambridge Judge Business School, the Asian Development Bank Institute(ADBI) and Fintechspace._

The objective of this study is to gain a better understanding of the fintech landscape in the ASEAN region and how it has been evolving within each country. The fintech ecosystem is constituted of interrelated and purposively congruent stakeholders including fintech companies, fintech institutions, investment firms, aggregators and policymakers. The study examines the different fintech business models that have emerged, the main business strategies taken to market, the type of customers served, and the principal technology innovations being adopted.

2/2/20, 21:15 - Vikas Business Phone: _FIAKS community thought Leader shared following information on the Budget 2020_ 

*Bilateral Netting* _will lay the foundation of a functioning corporate bond market in India_

The Union Budget announced yesterday has a number of radical measures that need elaboration. One of them is Bilateral Netting. This may seem like an arcane technical change, but it will lay the foundation of a functioning corporate bond market in India

*What is bilateral netting?* It allows two financial institutions to set off exposures to each other for the purposes of capital & margin. Illustration: Bank A has an exposure of Rs100 to Bank B, and Bank B has an exposure of Rs90 to Bank A. The gross exposure is Rs190 

‚ñ™With the imposition of capital requirements, the banks have to keep aside capital for Rs190. However, the net exposure is only Rs10. With bilateral netting, banks will only have to look at the net position thereby freeing up capital (in this illustration 19:1 ratio). 

‚ñ™Basel type capital requirements presume netting, and most countries already have it. India introduced Basel 3 without bilateral netting (multilateral is allowed). However, freeing up capital is not the biggest gain but the corporate bond market

‚ñ™Netting will allow development of a properly regulated corporate default swap market in line with international practice (RBI & SEBI are fully aware of the issues). In turn, this puts in place the necessary conditions for a liquid corporate debt market.

‚ñ™The Indian corporate bond market is effectively closed to most companies except the very largest. This opens the door for smaller companies to tap it. And yes, this will need to be properly regulated & supervised - including the integrity of rating agencies. 

‚ñ™In addition to the netting reform, the investment limit for FPIs in corporate bonds has been hiked from 9% to 15%. Other measures for boosting this market will be considered. Suggestions welcome.

2/3/20, 17:35 - Forum of Industry and Academic Knowledge Sharing: _security_: *Kraken Identifies Critical Flaw in Trezor Hardware Wallets*

This attack relies on voltage glitching to extract an encrypted seed. This initial research required some know-how and several hundred dollars of equipment, but we estimate that we (or criminals) could mass produce a consumer-friendly glitching device that could be sold for about $75.
We then crack the encrypted seed, which is protected by a 1-9 digit PIN, but is trivial to brute force.

The attack takes advantage of inherent flaws within the microcontroller used in the Trezor wallets. This unfortunately means that it is difficult for the Trezor team to do anything about this vulnerability without a hardware redesign. 

Until then, here is what you can do to protect yourself:
http://bit.ly/2vEOO5m

2/6/20, 15:06 - Forum of Industry and Academic Knowledge Sharing: _Webshells_ *Microsoft says it detects 77,000 active web shells on a daily basis*

_WHAT'S A WEB SHELL_

Web shells are crucial because of their functions. For non-technical  readers that have not encountered the term until today, a *"web shell" refers to a malicious program or script that's installed on a hacked server.*

They provide a visual interface that hackers can use to interact with the hacked server and its filesystem. Most web shell contain basic functions to rename, copy, move, and even edit or upload new files on a server. They can also be used to change file and directory permissions, or archive and download (steal) data from the server.
http://bit.ly/2UuxBpR
2/6/20, 18:02 - Vikas Business Phone: _cards biz_ *Australia central bank looks to rid Visa, Mastercard of debit payments edge*

Banks must stop automatically directing debit card payments through the two global networks, and instead give retailers the cheaper option to use local network EFTPOS, Philip Lowe, the governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA), told reporters.

"Regulating here is not the preferred option but it is a fallback option if we don't see the required change," he said after a speech in Sydney.

Global card schemes MasterCard and Visa, alongside the major four banks, dominate card payments systems in Australia. EFTPOS is owned by domestic financial institutions and retailers.

2/7/20, 13:07 - Forum of Industry and Academic Knowledge Sharing: _Technology_: *Google has released a tool to spot faked and doctored images*

How it works: Assembler combines several existing techniques in academia for detecting common manipulation techniques, including changing image brightness and pasting copied pixels elsewhere to cover up something while retaining the same visual texture. It also includes a detector that spots deepfakes of the type created using StyleGAN, an algorithm that can generate realistic imaginary faces. These detection techniques feed into a master model that tells users how likely it is that an image has been manipulated. 

Why it matters: Fake images are among the harder things to verify, especially with the rise of manipulation by artificial intelligence. The window of opportunity for journalists and fact-checkers to react is also rapidly shrinking, as disinformation spreads at speed and scale.

A unicorn startup or unicorn company is a private company with a valuation over $1 billion. *As of January 2020, there are more than 400 unicorns around the world.* Variants include a decacorn, valued at over $10 billion, and a hectocorn, valued at over $100 billion.

The highest valued Company, ByteDance, was founded in 2012 in Chinaüá®üá≥ and operates in AI sector. It offers content platforms that enable people to enjoy content powered by AI technology. ByteDance operates a dozen products accessible all over the world including TikTok, Vigo, Toutiao, TopBuzz and more.

Didi Chuxing, also based in China, is a multi-modal transportation platform. It was formed by the merger of Kuaidi Dache and DiDi Dache in 2012. The company offers a full range of app-based transportation options including taxi, express, premier, luxe, bus, designated driving, enterprise solutions, bike sharing, e-bike sharing, car sharing, and food delivery. 

JUUL Labs was founded in the United Statesüá∫üá∏ to provide smokers worldwide with an alternative to cigarettes that enables them to permanently switch. The company sells nicotine vaporizer designed for adult smokers.

2/17/20, 11:00 - Vikas Business Phone: *FIAKS community on sale of shares by CEO who is going to retire says*  Anonymous 

This is a standard practice in most banks. Senior management sells shares held in their own name either to their own family or to a investment company held by them. This allows them to trade freely without failing compliance norms.

Also many a times they sell and buy other stocks since trading in their own company shares is prohibited by insider trading norms.

Specifically in this case it could also be  considering his retirement the following reasons :

1) Estate Planning 
2) Investing in a new venture 
3) Just buying assets towards retirement 

Also If u see the pattern - typically upon vesting all the top  5-10 guys sell immediately.

Their holding is very low compared to the rest of the staff as compared to their net worth. There are very strict insider trading norms. They want liquidity without someone watching over them.
2/17/20, 11:03 - Aditya Birla Piush Kothari Payment Bank NnR: There are insider trading regulations. On top of it, organizations have their own guidelines on trading of shares. If it is within those norms it should be just fine and not subject to unnecessary public scrutiny

The letter, sent in January, tells fintech firms that they must sign onto a "concrete plan" by July to move from methods such as screenscraping and using customer passwords to a new data collection method, says Reuters, citing sources.

The bank says that these methods are not secure and wants third parties to connect to an API that gives access to limited account data, decided by customers.

If firms do not agree, JPMorgan will block all automated access to the customer data, which is the lifeblood for many fintech firms and the data aggregators which serve them. Most firms have already agreed to JPMorgan's demands, says Reuters.

2/17/20, 17:18 - Forum of Industry and Academic Knowledge Sharing: _Health History_: *Our personal health history is too valuable to be harvested by the tech giants*

Health data paints a rich picture of our lives. Even if you remove your name, date of birth and NHS number to ‚Äúanonymise‚Äù yourself, a full health history will reveal your age, gender, the places where you have lived, your family relationships and aspects of your lifestyle.

Used in combination with other available information, this may be enough to verify that this medical history relates to you personally and to target you online. Consequently, whenever the NHS shares health data, even if it is anonymised, we need to have confidence in who it goes to and what they can do with it.

2/18/20, 19:23 - Forum of Industry and Academic Knowledge Sharing: _Online_: *What happens to our online lives after we die?*
Over the course of the next few decades, there will be more and more dead people on Facebook. In fact, according to some estimates, as early as 2060 the number of deceased users‚Äô accounts will exceed the number of accounts with a living person behind them.

But people‚Äôs ‚Äúdigital afterlives‚Äù extend far beyond Facebook. When a 21st century citizen dies, they often leave behind a trove of posts, private messages, and personal information on everything from Twitter to online bank records. Who owns this data, and whose responsibility is it to protect the privacy of the deceased? Faheem Hussain, a social scientist at Arizona State University in Tempe, has spent the past few years peering into the murky waters of how people, platforms, and governments manage the digital lives we leave behind.

2/19/20, 17:11 - Forum of Industry and Academic Knowledge Sharing: _Artificial intelligence_: *Algorithms might be better than us at predicting whether people will reoffend*

The research: Researchers at Stanford University and the University of California, Berkeley tried to recreate a 2018 experiment which found that humans with no training were just as good as a widely-used risk-assessment software program called COMPAS. Risk-assessment algorithms are trained on historical defendant data and are supposed to help judges determine whether a defendant should be kept in jail or be allowed out while awaiting trial. (We went into some of the problems with them in this interactive piece last year.)

Test the humans: The team used a dataset of COMPAS risk assessments covering about 7,000 real defendants and used it to create profiles for each one. These profiles were showed to 400 laypeople recruited through the Amazon Mechanical Turk, asking them to decide if they thought the person would commit another crime. The 2018 study found COMPAS was accurate about 65% of the time, and humans were closer to 67%. This new study managed to closely replicate these results.

*Real Time Payment systems & third party access*

There are multiple models for expanding the adoption and usage of digital payment 
solutions in a country, from card networks in the developed world to closed loop stored value 
wallets and Real-Time Payments (RTP) systems that facilitate bank account to bank account transactions at relatively low cost. 
In this report, we‚Äôll focus on RTP systems. More than 50 countries have rolled them out, with 
many more in the works. RTP systems are the rails for modern payment infrastructures, offering 
near-instant transactions with a minimum of friction for all parties. They fundamentally change 
how payments are made and the ways in which they can become embedded in the new digital 
economy.

2/20/20, 16:40 - Forum of Industry and Academic Knowledge Sharing: _A.I. regulation_: *Europe wants businesses to share their data and open up their A.I. systems for scrutiny*

When it comes to artificial intelligence, the Commission is trying to draw a distinction between low-risk and high-risk use cases. Where the risk to people‚Äôs fundamental rights is low, regulation should be light-touch. Here, the Commission is talking about voluntary schemes to let companies label their A.I. applications as safe. But where the risk is high, such as in health or policing applications, regulation will be extremely tight.

In these high-risk cases, there will have to be human oversight, the Commission said. *And that means giving regulators the ability to inspect what is going on inside the black box*. ‚ÄúAuthorities should be able to test and certify the data used by algorithms as they check cosmetics, cars or toys,‚Äù the Commission said.

*How Infinite Banking Makes It Possible To Become Your Own Bank*

Infinite banking is a process in which you create your own banking system by getting a dividend-paying permanent life insurance policy to work for you. Developed by economist Nelson Nash, infinite banking allows you to essentially become your own banker, with the freedom to access your policy‚Äôs cash value by borrowing from yourself ‚Äî and paying yourself back ‚Äî at any time. Imagine never having to worry about a credit check, high-interest payments or having to apply for a car or student loan ever again ‚Äî this could be a reality via infinite banking.

2/22/20, 19:20 - Vikas Business Phone: *KNOWLEDGE SPEAKS*: *FIAKS community Thought Leader on DDT & No Tax leakage* 

Prior to June 1997, dividends were taxed in the hands of shareholders, like any other income. However, for ease of administration and collection of tax at a single point, taxation of dividend was shifted from shareholders to companies distributing dividends, with such dividends being exempt from tax in the hands of shareholders.

Taxation of dividends at the shareholder level has made investment in jurisdictions like Mauritius and Hong Kong attractive, with tax treaties providing a beneficial tax rate of 5 per cent on dividends. However, having substance in these jurisdictions continues to govern the availability of treaty benefits.

Also, under the DDT regime, pooling investment vehicles like mutual funds used to suffer dual-level taxation:

1. DDT paid by the company distributing dividends to mutual funds; and 

2. DDT payable by mutual funds on distribution to unit-holders. 

While, under the proposed regime, there will be single-tier taxation in the hands of unit-holders. 

There is no tax leakage on distribution of dividend by the company to mutual funds.

===========================
FAB Queries  *What is DDT??*

*DDT mean Dividend Distribution Tax* 
Jargons made easy by FIAKS

2/23/20, 00:14 - Vikas Business Phone: *KNOWLEDGE SPEAKS*: *FIAKS community Thought Leader on DDT*

He Adds...Minority retail investors will benefit from this change, it will also lead to several unintentional anomalies. 

Indian promoters and *high net-worth individuals (HNIs) will face a significant increase in the overall tax incidence to 57%* (versus 47% in FY20) on dividend income.

Let assume,
‚ñ™Ô∏èProfit Before Tax (PBT) of a company is Rs. 100
‚ñ™Ô∏èCorporate tax is 25% including surcharge i.e. Rs. 25
‚ñ™Ô∏èProfit after tax (PAT) Rs. 75 i.e. available profit for distribution as dividend.
‚ñ™Ô∏èTax in the hands of HNIs Promoters is 43% _including surcharges & cess_
‚ñ™Ô∏èTax paid by individual is Rs. 32(75x 43%)
‚ñ™Ô∏èTotal tax on promoters' is Rs. 25+32 = Rs. 57.
*This change also brings in a disparity between Indian and MNC promoters with respect to the tax rates on dividend income* 
‚ñ™Indian promoters will be liable to pay tax at 43%.
‚ñ™Ô∏èCorporate foreign promoters will be charged 22%, or even lower (5% in some cases) if they are located in a country where the tax treaty provides beneficial rates.
*This provision needs to be rethought & discussed.*

Moreover, the creation of significant tax arbitrage is also a very likely possibility (in the hands of the recipient) between the two popular ways in which a company returns money to its shareholder
a. dividend
b. share buyback. 

Buybacks will be taxed at 23%, 
while Dividend income will be taxed in the hands of promoters or HNIs at an effective rate of 43%. 

So as an investor or promoter what do you prefer?

*So many companies may prefer buybacks over dividends to distribute profits. Many companies may, in fact, curtail dividends*.

Category III alternative investment funds (AIF) set up as a trust will be at a major disadvantage compared to Category I/II AIFs. This is because Category III AIFs do not have the pass-through status and will be taxed at a maximum marginal rate of 43%. 

Similarly, unit-linked insurance plans (Ulips) may lose attractiveness compared to mutual funds as insurance companies are liable to pay tax on dividend income at 12%, while mutual funds enjoy specific exemption (under Section 10 (23d)) on such income.

2/28/20, 11:44 - Forum of Industry and Academic Knowledge Sharing: _Tax havens_:
*Tax havens cost governments $200 billion a year. It‚Äôs time to change the way global tax works* 

About 40% of multinational profits or $650 billion are shifted each to such tax havens by multinational firms from all countries. The price tag on this type of behavior? $200 Bn. lost in global tax revenue. The reason that this behavior is possible is an antiquated tax code designed in the 1920‚Äôs. The solution will be a global overhaul of the corporate tax code: and this overhaul might not be that far away. In this article I investigate the question: What would a fair, functional global tax system look like in 2030 and how bleak is the alternative?

First things first: How is it that companies can use tax havens to avoid paying taxes all together? The answer lies in the current international tax code that treats a multinational firm not as one firm, but as a collection of national entities. For today‚Äôs global companies, each dollar of reported income in the US or Germany will be taxed at close to 30%, whereas income reported in Bermuda will be taxed at 0%. Tax minimizing strategies that shift profits to various low-tax regimes have been documented at major multinationals including Amazon, Google, IKEA, Nike and many others.
