6/12/20, 12:17 - Forum of Industry and Academic Knowledge Sharing: _FIAKS Bespoke_ *How Can A Prudent Fiscal Policy Work When Economic Activity Itself Is At A Standstill?*

Can prudent fiscal policy & interest rate management have any meaning when economic activity is almost at a standstill? 

Well, the answer to the above question is always a yes, finance and economics always matters, even when the exchange of goods and services is less, it still exists. Also, a fiscal policy focuses to manage liquidity. And talking about liquidity, India needed liquidity regardless of the scare anyway.While it took time for countries to jump back on their feet, central banks were always making sure that liquidity and stability were maintained. It‚Äôs not to get economic activities going right now but to make sure that it‚Äôs not coming to standstill and once the situation is controlled, it‚Äôs easier to press the reset button. On investment, that will continue with a bit harsher or conservative outlook and habits may change post lockdown and more opportunity may pop up. This question also depends upon how this cycle plays out and how long core businesses can sustain.

6/12/20, 18:08 - Forum of Industry and Academic Knowledge Sharing: *FINAL ANSWER TO FIAKS QUEST 79*

According to the founders, the *Top 3 Selling Points* for a candidate to join a start-up are:

*No.1*
Potential for future growth

*No.2*
Company Culture

*No.3*
Mission of the Start-up 

*Other prevalent selling points are:*

4. Quality of the current team

5. Problem-solving and innovation opportunities

6. Candidates ability to make an impact

7. Work/ Life Balance

8. Success of the Company till date

9. Salary/ Cash Compensation

10. Diversity of the current team

These responses are retrieved from *State of Startups*, a survey conducted by *First Round*. The survey garnered 950 responses. Responders included *start-up founders* as well as *employees*.

A solid 49.5% of the founders believe that the potential of a start-up for future growthüìà is it's biggest selling point. A glance at the employees' responses reveals that for them, it's their ability to make an impact (55.1%)

State of Startups, which started as an experiment in 2015 is now the industry's largest dataset on what it's like to run a start-up with 3600+ submissions and 190,000+ data points.

6/17/20, 18:34 - Vikas Business Phone: *Intellectual Speaks:FIAKS Community Experts on- "Isn‚Äôt WHATSAPP  competitor VISA?"*

*Views 11* CXO Fintech 

It's a hark back to core competencies. 

WA has a great consumer base, they are focused on providing a great CX.

Networks are good at laying interconnecting pipes. Banks are good at acquiring consumers.

Yes, vertical integration can (and does) take place, but it takes time to build, mature and most importantly, get consumer adoption. 

Until then, the *fastest GTM* is by harnessing power of complementary players. In this case,
WA (owns consumers and CX) while
MA/V have built Send/Visa Direct pipes to various Banks/card issuers.

6/18/20, 11:14 - Forum of Industry and Academic Knowledge Sharing: _FIAKS Bespoke_ *Banks Are Shut To Avoid Run On Deposits Then Why Not Stock Market Too?*

While banks fail and a moratorium is imposed upon the banks then why not a similar thing is being considered when the stock market is going down. 

It is said that stock markets are barometers of the economy, and rarely in the past, the markets over the world have been shut during big negative events. We are a part of the world market system and index funds/global funds are participating and if we close markets will lead to panic and will further slide. Even Spain and Italy have not closed markets and they are impacted more than us.

Share market is the only investment vehicle that is accessible in bad times like this. 

Other investments like real estate, gold, etc are not as a liquid even if you are ready to sell at a lower price and are accessible like stocks. The premise that by closing markets, there will be no impact is fallacious. Markets will go down even more once they reopen as we have to understand that our markets are impacted more by global flows and not domestic players.

6/19/20, 18:08 - Forum of Industry and Academic Knowledge Sharing: *FINAL ANSWER TO FIAKS QUEST 80*

The quest to happiness starts with awareness. Let's get ready to bust some myths!

*Statement 1*  - *FACT*
(Decluttering and organising your work space can lead to improved happiness.)

_Details:_ Research shows that cluttered spaces can have negative effects on our stress and anxiety levels, as well as our ability to focus, our eating choices, and even our sleep. It was observed that when participants cleared clutter from their work environment, they were better able to focus and process information, and their productivity increased.

*Statement 2* - *MYTH*
(Limiting daily working hours is unimportant as long as we accomplish our targets.)

_Details:_ Increasing trends in Work from Home and virtual, instant communication technologies have blurred lines between professional and personal lives. Even then, it remains crucially important to wellbeing and productivity that we maintain a good work-life balance. One way of achieving that is through fixed working hours.

*Statement 3* - *MYTH*
(It is not okay to have negative emotions like sadness, and they should be completely eliminated.)

_Details:_ Emotions are a spectrum and they are meant to be temporary. It is okay to feel sad or angry, as long as you are able to recover and bounce back. If you are unable to do so, know that getting help is not shameful. Rather, it's a sign of courage.

*Statement 4* - *MYTH*
(Taking breaks while working is always counterproductive.)

_Details:_ Everyone has their own style of working, depending on their attention span and other factors. While some of us prefer working for hours at a stretch, some benefit at taking breaks every other hour to re-energize. Being accommodative of different working styles will boost workplace productivity.

*Statement 5* - *MYTH*
(Depressive symptoms are the same for all individuals.)

_Details:_ Every single individual has a different experience of how they go through mental illnesses, be it anxiety, depression or any other problem. Just because a person is lonely doesn't mean they are depressed. Just because someone is extroverted does not mean they are not depressed. There are a few telling signs of depression but they might be difficult to tell if the individual unconsciously/ actively masks the symptoms.

Mental Health does not have a one-size-fits-all solution. We are all living in times of extreme stress and uncertainty. It is all the more important to develop empathy.

üëâüèΩ Listen. Listen to what your coworkers have to say.
üëâüèΩ Create an inclusive, healthy workspace.
üëâüèΩ It is alright to take a time-out for yourself.
üëâüèΩ 'Happy' is not the only positive emotion. Try to feel grateful, inspired, hopeful when the going gets tough. 
üëâüèΩ Be sensitive. Be aware.

Have a resourceful day ahead!üí´

6/22/20, 18:23 - Forum of Industry and Academic Knowledge Sharing: _FIAKS Bespoke_ *Why Are GDP Calculations So Confusing?*

We have GDP of X in year 1. It will become Y in year 2. The difference between Y and X is growth. Secondly, we don‚Äôt have equal GDP per day or months in terms of production (an output basis for GDP) or consumption (another way). Most of the consumption continues, at least for essential goods. So as demand picks up, it will recover part of the lost ground.

Now coming back to economics, the 1900s first half great depression was overcome through increased government spending. Unless the government does not contribute substantially to business confidence, the economy may enter into a recession.

GDP calculations are inadequate measure of economy.
GDP calculates trade not production of goods and services.

*View 15* _CXO Banker_  üáÆüá≥ 

Well I guess the parties involved in the refund process are the ecom company (merchant aggregator), the merchant, merchant‚Äôs banker, ecom company‚Äôs banker, and the customer‚Äôs bank. Plus NPCI most likely or an equivalent router.

So this 6-way recon may take time. At each level if it takes T+1 to recon&settle back&forth, the refund duration adds up to 7 days. Add a couple of days buffer.

That said, even as I write this, this process sounds reeeally *ANCIENT*

*View 23*: _CXO Banker UAE_ üá¶üá™

It‚Äôs all parties as they require reconciliation of the entire transaction before it is refunded.. having said that if automation is put in place to reconcile them the timeline significantly reduces to instant refund for straight through cases and at a maximum of regulatory 2 working days for suspect cases

EY failed for more than three years to request crucial account information from a Singapore bank where Wirecard claimed it had up to ‚Ç¨1bn in cash ‚Äî a routine audit procedure that could have uncovered the vast fraud at the German payments group.

The accountancy firm, which audited Wirecard for a decade, has come under fire after the once high-flying fintech company filed for insolvency this week, revealing that ‚Ç¨1.9bn in cash probably did ‚Äúnot exist‚Äù. 

People with first-hand knowledge told the Financial Times that the auditor between 2016 and 2018 did not check directly with Singapore‚Äôs OCBC Bank to confirm that the lender held large amounts of cash on behalf of Wirecard. Instead, EY relied on documents and screenshots provided by a third-party trustee and Wirecard itself. 

Wirecard is the latest scandal to embroil a Big Four accounting firm.
‚ÄúThe big question for me is what on earth did EY do when they signed off the accounts?‚Äù said a senior banker at a lender with credit exposure to Wirecard.

OCBC declined to comment. The lender did not receive any query from EY in relation to Wirecard between 2016 and 2018, the person added.

The Big Four accounting firm had issued unqualified audits of Wirecard for a decade despite increasing questions over suspect accounting practices from journalists and short sellers. 

An ‚Äúout of country‚Äù team at EY is reviewing the work carried out by its German auditors, according to a person close to the firm.

The German accounting watchdog FREP is probing Wirecard‚Äôs balance sheet, and the country‚Äôs auditor oversight body APAS has begun looking into EY‚Äôs work. EY declined to comment on the regulatory investigation and details of its work. FREP and APAS declined to comment. 

The purported accounts at Asian banks play a pivotal role in Wirecard‚Äôs accounting fraud that culminated in the group filing for insolvency on Thursday. 
According to the company‚Äôs former management, the accounts were used to settle transactions with partners who acted on Wirecard‚Äôs behalf in countries where it did not have its own licences to process electronic payments. Yet it is now unclear if the accounts ‚Äî let alone the money allegedly deposited there ‚Äî ever existed.

Wirecard had told its auditors that the money moved late last year from OCBC to banks in the Philippines, where supposedly there was now ‚Ç¨1.9bn deposited.

A special audit by KPMG could not obtain original documents from the banks to prove deposits existed. EY was told this month by the banks that paperwork it had previously seen on the Philippine accounts was ‚Äúspurious‚Äù and they did not exist.

The head of audit at a rival accounting firm to EY said: ‚ÄúIt is beyond the realms of reality that EY wouldn‚Äôt have had [the bank balance confirmations] unless they did a very poor audit. Cash is easy to audit. If investors can‚Äôt trust the cash number, what can they trust?‚Äù

In a statement issued on Thursday, EY said there were ‚Äúclear indications that this was an elaborate and sophisticated fraud, involving multiple parties around the world in different institutions, with a deliberate aim of deception‚Äù. The company argued that ‚Äúeven the most robust audit procedures may not uncover this kind of fraud‚Äù.

Hansrudi Lenz, professor of accounting at W√ºrzburg university, told the Financial Times that it was ‚Äúnot sufficient‚Äù for an auditor to rely on account confirmations that were provided by third parties. ‚ÄúThe auditor needs to have full control over the delivery of account confirmation,‚Äù he said, adding that this was stipulated by procedural guidelines.

Germany‚Äôs small shareholder lobby group SdK on Friday said it filed criminal complaints against the EY auditors who signed Wirecard‚Äôs accounts between 2016 and 2018, accusing them of violating professional duties.

Accounts published by Wirecard showed that five different EY partners signed its accounts over the past five years. Among them is Andreas Loetscher, who co-led EY‚Äôs audits into Wirecard between 2015 and 2017 and a year later joined Deutsche Bank as chief accounting officer.

Deutsche Bank said: ‚ÄúThere are many open questions with regard to Wirecard. We highly appreciate our work with Andreas Loetscher. Moreover‚Äâ.‚Äâ.‚Äâ.‚Äâthe presumption of innocence of course applies to him as well.‚Äù 

Wirecard insolvency, Brussels to probe German regulator, Federal Reserve bans buybacks
EY is already facing a class-action lawsuit in Germany brought by Wirecard investors. Wolfgang Schirp, a Berlin-based lawyer who is working on the case against the audit firm, said: ‚ÄúIt is frightening how long Wirecard was able to operate without being objected to by the auditors. We have been monitoring Wirecard since 2008 and have collected very extensive material. It was always clear that something was wrong.‚Äù

Akshay Naheta, a SoftBank executive who led an investment in Wirecard last year, attacked EY on Twitter last week. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm totally baffled by the lack of competence and responsibility displayed by E&Y,‚Äù he wrote. ‚ÄúAs an organisation that is meant to protect all stakeholders ‚Äî creditors and shareholders ‚Äî in companies, both public and private, they have materially failed in their fiduciary duties.‚Äù

For years EY has said it wants to expand its roster of clients on Germany‚Äôs DAX 30 index as it audits fewer companies than its rivals KPMG and PwC. EY earned nearly ‚Ç¨10m for its audits of Wirecard over the past decade.

The Wirecard fraud is one of several international accounting scandals that have emerged on EY‚Äôs watch this year, including at NMC Health and Luckin Coffee.

Corporate credit card is something we have all discussed at some point who are founders or even who manage P/Ls and that trend has picked up worldwide, including in India, however the terms of corporate credit cards is so abysmally bad that most folks who can calculate enough finance wouldn‚Äôt touch (unless they are very young and very small at GMV level).

So what I see as difference is on credit limits:
Corporate credit cards talk about 25 K to 5 L vs some say 1% transaction value vs personal credit cards in multiple forms sometimes have over 10 L available on account. Between 2/3 founders this credit limit can go up 20-25 L

There seems to be no added benefits that corporate credit cards accrue over personal credit cards like points or miles etc.

Corporate credit cards have ~14-15% annual interest rate vs personal credit cards have a 35-42% annual interest rates, which is the only real benefit, but is the business then betting on delinquency and credit defaults?

This is across all new players in the game and not specific to one player, I have personally spoken to at least 3-5 very bright teams, all of whom have some banking experience, solving this problem.

Japanese supercomputer *Fugaku* zipped past all competitors to claim the top spot in the twice-annual ranking of the world's most powerful computational machines released by research project *Top500*. 

Fugaku, which was developed by *Fujitsu* in cooperation with the federal *RIKEN Center for Computational Science (R-CCS)*, was able to perform almost three times as many computations per second as former leader of the list, U.S.-based supercomputer Summit. The supercomputer also had the most cores of all computers ranked, the highest theoretical peak performance for computations and the highest power capacity.

Speaking at the ISC 2020 conference in June, Satoshi Matsuoka, Director of R-CCS, said that although Fugaku was scheduled to start up next year, *Japan‚Äôs government decided it should be deployed now to help combat Covid-19*. He cited that it was being used to study how the virus behaves, what existing drugs might be repurposed to counter it, and how a vaccine could be made.

_To know more, read:_
https://top500.org/lists/top500/2020/06/

7/10/20, 18:03 - Forum of Industry and Academic Knowledge Sharing: *FINAL ANSWER TO FIAKS QUEST 83*

The barriers to digital transformation, as perceived by executives, are ranked by proportion as follows: 

*1A-2B-3C-4D-5E*

*A - 1.* Lack of digital skills (93%)
*B - 2* Cultural and Behavioral Factors (85%)
*C - 3.* Lack of understanding of digital trends (77%)
*D - 4.* Organisational structure not aligned (75%)
*E - 5.* Inadequate IT infrastructure (68%)

We all could use a little laugh, couldn't we! As the third hint mentioned, the answer was hidden in the questionüòÑ

Cornerstone Advisors undertook a study of executives to understand the perception of digital transformation in the banking sector. A whopping 93% of the executives responded that lack of digital skills was a barrier! As Ron Shevlin (MD of Fintech Research at Cornerstone Advisors) puts it,
 _"The path to digital transformation isn‚Äôt‚Äîand won‚Äôt be‚Äîa straight line. We‚Äôll see periods of faster transformation followed by slower periods as institutions reach and adapt to changes."_

Digital transformation is a structural change with *4 primary requirements:*
Complete overhaul of legacy technology, Maturation of A.I., A new generation of senior execs, and More shocks to the system (in addition to the current crisis). 

Therefore, the popular notion that the current crisis has helped accelerate the digital transformation of banking needs a severe reality check along with sustained efforts to actually realise the process.

This pandemic has put everyone on work from home mode and to surprise many companies are considering it to be the future of work. It seems like a new reality. Well, on the contrary, every company cannot consider work from home to be the future reality. Are banks designed for remote working? Also, most of the banks are not completely digitally oriented yet, and thus for such banks running clearing and payment systems is a challenge and hindrance for work from home.

*CITI GROUP*: _Second Quarter 2020 (Apr-May-June)Results_

*Citigroup Inc. today reported net income for the second quarter 2020 of $1.3 billion, or $0.50 per diluted share, on revenues of $19.8 billion. This compared to net income of $4.8 billion, or $1.95 per diluted share, on revenues of $18.8 billion for the second quarter 2019.*

‚ñ™Ô∏èCitigroup revenues of $19.8 billion in the second quarter 2020 increased 5%, primarily reflecting the higher revenues in Fixed Income Markets and Investment Banking, partially offset by the lower revenues in GCB.
‚ñ™Ô∏èCitigroup operating expenses of $10.4 billion in the second quarter 2020 decreased 1%, as efficiency savings and lower marketing and other discretionary spend more than offset higher compensation expense, investments and COVID-19 related expenses.
‚ñ™Ô∏èCitigroup cost of credit of $7.9 billion in the second quarter 2020 compared to $2.1 billion in the prior-year period, reflecting the ACL builds related to the deterioration in Citi‚Äôs macroeconomic outlook since the end of the first quarter, the corporate loan downgrades and the qualitative management adjustment.
‚ñ™Ô∏èCitigroup net income of $1.3 billion in the second quarter 2020 declined 73%, driven by the higher cost of credit, partially offset by the higher revenues and a lower effective tax rate. Citigroup‚Äôs effective tax rate was 9% in the current quarter compared to 22% in the second quarter 2019, reflecting a higher relative impact from tax advantaged investments and other tax benefit items this quarter given the lower level of pre-tax income.
‚ñ™Ô∏èCitigroup‚Äôs allowance for credit losses on loans was $26.4 billion at quarter end, or 3.89% of total loans, compared to $12.5 billion, or 1.82% of total loans, at the end of the prior-year period. Total non-accrual assets grew 58% from the prior-year period to $5.9 billion. Consumer non-accrual loans declined 7% to $1.8 billion, while corporate non-accrual loans of $4.0 billion increased from $1.7 billion in the prior year period.
‚ñ™Ô∏èCitigroup‚Äôs end-of-period loans were $685 billion as of quarter end, largely unchanged from the prior-year period. Excluding the impact of foreign exchange translation6, end-of-period loans grew 1%, driven by 5% growth in ICG, partially offset by lower loans in GCB and the continued wind-down of legacy assets in Corporate / Other.
‚ñ™Ô∏èCitigroup‚Äôs end-of-period deposits were $1.2 trillion as of quarter end, an increase of 18% from the prior-year period. In constant dollars, Citigroup‚Äôs end-of-period deposits increased 20%, driven by 15% growth in GCB and 22% growth in ICG.
Citigroup‚Äôs book value per share of $83.41 and tangible book value per share of $71.15 each increased 5% versus the prior-year period, driven by a reduction in common shares outstanding. At quarter end, Citigroup‚Äôs CET1 Capital ratio was 11.5%, up from the prior quarter, primarily reflecting a decline in risk-weighted assets. Citigroup‚Äôs SLR for the second quarter 2020 was 6.7%, an increase from the prior quarter. During the quarter, Citigroup returned a total of $1.1 billion to common shareholders in the form of dividends.

7/21/20, 11:09 - Forum of Industry and Academic Knowledge Sharing: _FIAKS Bespoke_ *Promoting Startups: Isn‚Äôt This A Role Of Bank Too?*

It is very difficult for a start-up to get a loan from a commercial bank or lender. To them, they are in fact the riskiest loans of any that a bank or lender might encounter. So understandably they are nervous about startup loans. Because startups don‚Äôt have business credit of their own, the bank has to look at the credit of the people who own the business. Funding from the bank would involve the usual process of sharing the business plan and the valuation details, along with the project report, based on which the loan is sanctioned. This is exactly the mindset that needs to be drastically changed. This mindset literally kills and discourages many startups to even start it out.

<200>  *FIAKS community Debates Tonight* 

FIAKS questions the use of the connector that is used for doing biometric authentication while issuing SIM card  or while opening the bank account. 

Watch the blue colour connector in the pic. If you walk into any electronic outlet then  several such connectors with STORAGE capacity are available. 

The KYC official with an intent to fraud can easily store customer  details in this blue device.  *Isn‚Äôt this risky ??*

*Question 1* Why are cant we eliminate these blue colour connecting devices 

*Question 2* How can telco or bank  say that this device can‚Äôt store customer details? What safe guards are put to derisk ?

7/21/20, 20:36 - Vikas Business Phone: *Intellectual Speaks:FIAKS Community Expert on  Blue color connectors used says* 

Biometric service is secured through what we call "RD Service" and associated software in PC or Mobile. RD stands for Registered Devices. This software is in the app or in PoS/PC. The USB to USB-C or USB to MicroUSB connector like this cannot steal any biometric info due to RD Services and associated software. Due to mobiles having USB-C/MicroUSB and PCs having normal USB, Biometric manufacturers cannot have so many variants of USB as customer may use the same Biometric with mobile and/or PC which will have different type of USB terminations. This typically does not compromise any security.

*Question*  Registered Devices?  -   Only mobile and scan device is registered here. *Dont you think this blue colour device should also be registered*

Blue colour device is *breaking* the secure point to point (ie mobile handset to biometric scan device) connectivity. This exposes a risk of data theft and security? Isn‚Äôt it ?

*FIAKS award winner on PAN AADHAR MATCHING says* 
Pan AADHAR name matching is an interesting challenge.
Indian names with surname combinations can pose a serious challenge when comparing two id docs. 
Many banks follow different practices. For ease of customer journey it is better that we prevent abusive practices in the beginning by using multiple name matching algorithms in iterative mode. 
If one does not match, follow up with another till there is a reasonable level of confidence to believe there is no fraud. Depending upon each bank‚Äôs risk appetite you could set up a manual eyeballing for exceptions after the account is opened and kept In a frozen status. Once the 4 eye principle is met, the freeze could be lifted. 
That would be a balanced approach

7/24/20, 18:12 - Forum of Industry and Academic Knowledge Sharing: *FINAL ANSWER TO FIAKS QUEST 85*

_The answers to this week's quest are:_

*1.* Companies with the worst privacy practices are *80%* more likely to suffer a data breach 

*2.* Companies in the lowest quartile of privacy scores lost *600%* more records than companies with better privacy scores.

*3.* *Government & Educational websites* are 15x more likely to experience a breach than commercial sites


These are some of the key findings of a report realeased by Osano - analyzing the relationship between a company‚Äôs privacy practices and their likelihood of experiencing a data breach. 

Some of the other important facts established in this report are mentioned below >>

The correlations between data breaches and Osano Privacy Scores stem from many causes including willful ignorance, oversight of privacy best practices that increase risk exposure, and company culture around responsible data stewardship. 

According to the Internal Auditors Research Foundation, *third parties were responsible for 2 out of every 3 data breaches.* A tightly linked finding was that the worst privacy actors are the least likely to be able to retrospectively identify the root cause of a breach.

Poor privacy practices translate beyond mere financial market setbacks - *they play with the confidence of the shareholders and consumers.* As Osano Co-Founder and CEO, Arlo Gilbert noted, _‚ÄúThere is a perception that privacy issues are akin to a speeding ticket -- a risk worth running. Companies that don‚Äôt change their perception are facing higher odds of experiencing a data breach and losing the trust they‚Äôve built with their customers.‚Äù_

To know more, read on:
https://www.techrepublic.com/article/companies-with-poor-privacy-practices-are-80-more-apt-to-suffer-data-breach/

*The Countries with the Least Gender Gap, along with their gender parity scores(0-1), are:*

*No.1*

Norwayüá≥üá¥ (0.842)

Swedenüá∏üá™ (0.820)

*No.5*
Nicaraguaüá≥üáÆ (0.804)

*Rankings from 6-10 are as follows:*

6. New Zealandüá≥üáø (0.799)
7. IrelandüáÆüá™ (0.798)
8. Spainüá™üá∏ (0.795)
9. Rwandaüá∑üáº (0.791)
10. Germanyüá©üá™ (0.787)

This data is sourced from the World Economic Forum's Global Gender Gap Index 2020 Rankings.

The index benchmarks national gender gaps on *economic, education, health and political criteria* and provides country rankings that allow for effective comparisons across regions and income groups.In 2020, the Global Gender Gap score (based on the population-weighted average) stands at 68.6%. This means that, on average, the gap is narrower, and the *remaining gap to be closed is 31.4%*

All the top five countries have closed at least 80% of their gaps, and the best performer (Iceland) has closed 82% of its 
gap so far.

On the other end of the spectrum, conflict-ridden, developing countries like Syria, Iraq, Pakistan and Yemen have starkingly low scores.

The overall gender gap performance is a synthesis of performances across the four dimensions composing the index‚Äîthe Economic Participation, Educational Attainment, Health and Survival and Political Empowerment subindexes. As such it masks significant differences in gender gaps across dimensions. 

Overall, this year‚Äôs positive result has been driven mainly by a progress on the Political Empowerment subindex, as well as by marginal improvements on the Health and Survival and Educational Attainment subindexes. Conversely, the progress towards gender parity in terms of Economic Participation and Opportunity registers a retraction.

To see the ranks of all 153 countries, refer to *Page 9* of the following PDF.

8/7/20, 18:08 - Forum of Industry and Academic Knowledge Sharing: *FINAL ANSWER TO FIAKS QUEST 87*

*Q1* Name the MIT developed AI System that rates similarity between two pieces of code-
*A1: Machine Inferred Code Similarity (MISIM)*
MISIM ostensibly outperforms current state-of-the-art systems by up to 40 times, showing promise for applications from code recommendation to automated bug fixing.


*Q2.* Which bank recently declared a partnership to develop digital credit cards?
*A2: JPMorgan Chase*
The banking giant‚Äôs commercial cards team is partnering with Bay Area startup Marqeta to launch digital-only credit cards. This will allow JPMorgan's corporate cards to work in mobile wallets such as Apple Pay immediately without having to wait for a physical version of the card in the mail. 


*Q3.* On July 27, which entity filed a lawsuit against Google for using browsing history without explicit consent?
*A3: The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC)*
The ACCC alleges that Google misled consumers by not properly informing them about technology that tracked a user‚Äôs internet browsing on non-Google sites, and combined it with the personal information of their Google accounts.


*Q4.* Which middleware solution is enabling Coca-Cola bottling supply chain to access the decentralised finance ecosystem?
*A4: The Baseline Protocol*
The Protocol offers a set of tools‚Äîincluding zero-knowledge proofs‚Äîthat allow business transactions, smart contracts, and communications to remain private when organizations use Ethereum‚Äôs public mainnet. 


*Q5.* Which is the first publicly known threat actor to incorporate the DNS-over-HTTPS (DoH) protocol in its attacks?
*A5: Oilrig(Iranian)*
According to Vincente Diaz, Oilrig operators began using a new utility called DNSExfiltrator as part of their intrusions into hacked networks.
DNSExfiltrator is an open-source project available on GitHub that creates covert communication channels by funneling data and hiding it inside non-standard protocols.

8/12/20, 08:45 - Fintech Aayush NnR: Was reading some Covid-19 articles about T-cells memory helping to fight all kinds of viruses etc. long story short, ended up calculating a few figures on my mobile while looking at trends for Indian cities.

- All major Indian cities seem to be at their somewhere between 45-60 day range and then tapering off between 90 to 120 days
- The best way to judge the peak is calculating 1% of total population for a city at 2020 numbers and then seeing in which 30 day period did they get affected, that period would be the peak.
- Almost all major Indian cites with big populations have peaked, Bangalore being the latest, and all of Bangalore‚Äôs peak will be today minus 7 to next 7-10 days, and will then inevitably taper off.
- Cities will taper off to a stable 500 number between 90-120, 250 beyond that and will stay that way pretty much not tapering down much beyond that.
- All this assumes similar or growing number is testing + stable or decreasing test positivity rate.
- Big cities = Assumed or close to 1 Cr population
- Smaller cities will peak slower but also taper slower as a %age
- One should ideally account for net migration in the same time period
- Tier II / Tier III / Tier N India will face difficulties starting end of this month / beginning of next month, whoever hasn‚Äôt reached the 1% population figure, however because of density this number might vary between 0.75 to 1.25% for a city for the peak period of 30 days.
- Total population affected will be 7.5% in best case, 10% in worst case, within a major Indian city. 

The reason I shared this here is because I think businesses will start getting back up after the 120-150 day period from the time a city did 0.00025% of positive cases / population at the beginning, peaking at 0.003% of daily cases / population, tapering off to the same 0.00025% number over the next 4-5 months.

What is the curve following?
Some sort of a half-life, at least while tapering, so also a mirror while growing. Retrospectively, all this sounds pretty obvious because it will form a bell-curve going through the population, which is what this is - The key however is the ~1% population positivity in a 30 day period - That is how we will get to know any peak therefore take any personal or professional calls that we might need to take.

If I get the time today, which I most probably won‚Äôt, will dive deeper on an actual laptop, and see how far all this holds true for real, and will update. Hope this helps someone in someway in some planning via a (over)simplified heuristics - if a city hasn‚Äôt done ~1% Covid-19 spread within a given 30 day period, it hasn‚Äôt peaked.

8/12/20, 11:07 - Forum of Industry and Academic Knowledge Sharing: _FIAKS Bespoke_ *Ban On Chinese Apps: How?*

Are there previous instances of a Government asking Google or Apple to remove apps and they have complied? China has of course banned some social media apps but it is that at AppStore level or network level.

Well, the law of the land prevails. If the authorities of the local law ask Apple and Google, with valid reasoning and proofs the stores would comply. There have been past precedents. The other point is that even if the App stores have the app, the government can do port/IP blocks to make the apps pretty unusable from a content perspective at least. *View 11* _COO MNC_

He will get exposed only if he is hiding something. The reason why he is managing digital payments is because he understands customers and payments due to his rich experience. The juniors in his team who understand the tech jargon do not understand banking and the key skill here is banking. So, he should not pretend that he understands this jargon and ask for clarification whenever needed.

8/14/20, 18:03 - Forum of Industry and Academic Knowledge Sharing: *FINAL ANSWER TO FIAKS QUEST 88*

The countries with the Highest share of Female Adult Population engaged in Innovation-Driven Entrepreneurial Activity are as follows:

*No.1*
 Chileüá®üá± (32.4%)

*No.2*
U.S.A.üá∫üá∏ (16.6%)

*No.3*
United Arab Emirates (12.6%)


According to a study carried out in 40 countries and territories by the Global Entrepreneurship Research Association, female entrepreneurs are especially common in developing nations like Angola, as well as in developed countries Chile and the U.S. Many developed nations in Europe have very low rates of female entrepreneurs, according to the study.

The researchers distinguish between necessity-driven entrepreneurship, which can be caused by a lack of formal employment opportunities in a country, and innovation-driven entrepreneurialism, which exists in countries with well-developed formal job markets.

While there is a positive correlation between male and female levels of early-stage entrepreneurial activity, and while the majority of countries continue to have male levels of entrepreneurial activity in excess of that of females, in 2019 there are *three GEM-participating economies where the female rate exceeds the male rate*

8/19/20, 19:51 - Vikas Business Phone: *Intellectual Speaks:FIAKS Community Experts who successfully expanded businesses overseas on ‚ÄúCAN LOCAL FINTECH BECOME GLOBAL‚Äù*  says  Anonymously 


Founder led Fintech (not Infosys type companies) will find it difficult to be global organisation. They have baniya approach which may have worked well in home country. However for overseas market expansion I have serious doubts. 

1. founder needs to have very important ingredient called ‚ÄúPatience‚Äù. Gestation period in these markets are too long. 

2. I have worked with Indian, Nepalese and Bangladeshi founders who were settled in US and Singapore. These Fintech founders are *visionary only on power point presentation*. They don‚Äôt want to understand difference between expense and investment. They want to make quick money leaving half baked products /projects. Rarely you will find a fintech founder working for success stories in these global markets. Top of his mind is always Money ! Money!! and only Money!!!

Founder just want to show that they are global company to the world with couple of sign-ups. No serious intent to serve the overseas market.. they looking at it more from valuations perspective and better exit for PE/VC

3. Most founders are looking for partnership with large tech organisation with international presence as they offer partnerships  *FREE*. Results of such partnerships are known. Fintech founders loves anything FREE. 

4. Try raising voice with local Singaporean or Vietnamese. They will quit the job next day. Can you ever imagine staff taking a nap post lunch. It‚Äôs a cultural shock to these founders üòÑ. They are use to treating their employees as slaves with glorified titles.

I would prefer working for European or Brit or Canadian founder as they talk dollars. Indian or Nepalese or Bangladeshi founder will keep calculating in home currency and will always be in state of shocküòÑ.

8/19/20, 22:15 - Vikas Business Phone: *FIAKS community member on Can LOCAL FINTECH BECOME GLOBAL says* 


*View 62*  _CXO fintech_ 

We have to be a little more specific about what we mean by 'global'... When social, cultural, economic and political variations decide the acceptability of solutions... Universal acceptance is a rare phenomenon if not impossible.So, let us examine the nuances of being global first. Is acceptance of a solution in one country apart from its home country make it global? Or would acceptance in one continent apart from its home continent make it global... Or is Billability in one currency other than the home currency of the home country make it global?

I have not come across a proper, unanimously accepted definition of 'global' till now.

Therefore, the entire discussion is on a premise that is perceived differently by the different responders...

When we talk of Products  in Fintech... Multi Continental /Multi Country acceptance requires assimilation of user aspirations from different milieu all consolidated in a fully functional solution that can factor in the situational conflicts that may arise due to diversity of user aspirations

8/24/20, 11:11 - Forum of Industry and Academic Knowledge Sharing: _FIAKS bespoke_ *Should There Be A Restriction Of One Customer One UPI ID?*

_Doesn‚Äôt it lead to a risk of money laundering?_

Firstly, it‚Äôs a defeat of the purpose of UPI i.e. convenience, specific purpose VPA, temporary VPA, etc. The idea behind making UPI open is to allow innovation to flourish and not get stifled by controls.

Customers can not only create multiple VPA in each bank but also the same bank account can be linked as a new VPA in PSPs too. And why not? That‚Äôs the whole advantage of VPA. No permanent binding like one account number, a label similar to a single-use virtual card number. The underlying bank account remains the same, anti-money laundering is at  the bank account level, not UPI ID, velocity checks are on the bank account, not UPI ID. Since,the volume & value limits for UPI are at the account level, hence having multiple UPI IDs doesn‚Äôt matter.

*View 23*

A1 . No additional banking license required to serve the same 100 million customers. Sponsor bank relationships is the best way forward. 

RBI is run by professional with deep understanding of markets. Nothing wrong if the best practices from any other part of the world is replicated by regulators in the home country. 

Regulatory authorities will find it difficult to issue digital banking license.  *As the fresh license category may give advantage to digital banks over payments bank*. There will be no takers for any license category with  more restriction compared to  payments bank.

A2. The term Neo Bank is fashionable these days however I can share several successful usecases like eWallets, Agency banking, cross border remittances, gift card program  to name few.

A3. Core banking platform providers are unable to service the need of the bank who want to be agile like Fintech‚Äôs and looking for programable platform. They need platforms on which product can be configured within hours as against several months by the core banking  platform providers. 

A4. Yes core banking providers can surely service this requirement of the large banks. But it‚Äôs like making elephant dance. 
Please note they are already collaborating with several fintech companies to service these needs of the banks. Also the revenue side, banks are run smart bankers  who do ROI every product they launch. Some may not be profitable but that‚Äôs the cost of innovation and cost of learning 

Let regulatory not become another boss of the consumer banking heads. Regulators have better job to do.

8/27/20, 00:07 - Remitr Sandeep Todi Co-founder NnC: Having a digital banking licence is a good thing, similar to E-money or else PI licence in Europe. Both are different in scope and regulation, so RBI has to decide which way it is going to lead to. However, if it imposes the kind of restrictions that it did on payments banks then it will defeat the purpose.

Secondly, to spur innovation it makes sense to have a 2-tier licence, one which is bank sponsored and therefore ultimately the funds are held with and insured by a Tier1 bank. The second could be an independent licence which carries more responsibility and therefore also allows more flexibility to the new entrants.

Third and very important is to include international payments in the purview of digital banking licence. In today's age purely local banking has its own wide use case but it will severely limit innovation for global opportunities.

As to the 2nd question, neobanks are designed to solve for the consumer and not for the banking incumbents. Neobanks are designed around specific problems which are not solved by banks. This question is redundant because if banks were able to solve then neos would not exist.

Regulatory oversight on revenue of bank products does not exist per se, so whether its a regular bank or a neobank, there is hardly any role for a banking regulator to play. You could argue that sometimes neobanks have predatory pricing but:
a) considering that they are challengers and not incumbents, they can hardly be called predatory
b) pricing is always a model based on a mix of profitable and not-profitable products so it is wrong to single out pricing
c) with any bank you will have profitable and non-profitable customers, so again its hard to pin down what is fair pricing

Inter-city vs intra-city is a false dichotomy / competition. Both are variants of the same problem and both are volume led markets at both supply and demand end.

Therefore the conclusion is foregone.
9/2/20, 01:16 - Fintech Netpay Ajay Founder NnC: Not really. There is probably a bit overlap in India due to negligible cost difference between chaffeured & self-drive. Globally, anywhere else you go Avis / Hertz are primarily for long distance self-drive rentals, while Uber is for city point-to-point drops.

9/2/20, 01:26 - Fintech Aayush NnR: All new cars are self-drive rentals, all mid-aged cars are chauffeur driven, all used cars are pure ride-hailing cabs.

The entire lifecycle is managed at scale by one company like Uber because they are the only kind of company (+ other ride hailing apps) that own the volume for such things to scale at the lowest total cost of ownership - Non-owned cars and non-owned riders are a non-differentiated commodity volume business, where lowest price will always win.

This is not an India phenomenon, it‚Äôs a global phenomenon, which will only speed up, but will perhaps be seen way more aggressively in India, because of price dynamics, but acquisition / merger in western markets will actually be faster, because the conclusion is foregone.

*Policy responses to fintech: a cross-country overview*

This report surveys 31 jurisdictions on their policy responses to fintech developments. The key aim of the paper is to provide a cross-country overview of the responses that financial authorities have pursued in relation to fintech. The paper is based on responses to a survey conducted in early 2019 by the Financial Stability Institute (FSI), which was supplemented by a comprehensive review of published regulations and documents.

The _2020 Aid Transparency Index by PWYF_ shows significant improvement in donors‚Äô overall transparency compared to 2018. 

The 2020 Aid Transparency Index shows a mixed picture of some donors continuing to perform well, others making significant progress, and some treading water, with few changes or improvements in their aid transparency over the past two years. There are also persistent issues with disclosure of project performance data as well as contracts and tender information and sub-national locations of activities.


Aid transparency should also inform learning and evaluation both during and after the crisis. By publishing timely results and evaluations‚Äîboth positive and negative‚Äîaid donors can monitor the progress of interventions and learn from what works, what does not work, and why. As the human impact on the natural world increases the likelihood of more pandemics in the future, it is imperative that we take full advantage of the learning opportunities from the current mobilisation of international aid so that we may be better prepared to prevent or respond to future outbreaks.

*View 4* _Banking & Fintech Expert_
this is just a reference rate. Like LIBOR. Your interest is a margin over this. If you see your home loan or car loan or business loan letter it would say MCLR plus x%. *Only inter-bank borrowing happens at this rate*

And AAs, Bs and Gs of the world get this rate form banks. *Thats exactly the point I am making* Chedda, Agarwal and sons, Udippi wont get

*FAB query?*  what is MCLR 
Marginal Cost of Fund based lending Rate 

The *MCLR* and *Base Rate* may appear to be quite similar on the surface. After all, they were implemented with the same objective in mind and are loosely based on similar principles. However, there are crucial factors in each case which separate the two rates. The differences have been tabulated as shown below.

*Base Rate*
 -Based on average cost of funds
-Calculated by considering minimum rate of return/profit margin
-Base is also governed by operating expenses, and expenses needed to maintain cash reserve ratio

*MCLR*
-Based on marginal/incremental cost of funds
-Calculated by considering tenor premium
-The MCLR is also determined by considering deposit rates and repo rates, along with operating
-costs and cost of maintaining cash reserve ratio

9/10/20, 22:10 - Fintech Easy2lend Riaz Maniyar NnR: =====================
The acronym FOMO may be relatively new, but the fear of missing out has driven human beings since time immemorial. Our social herd instincts naturally push us towards choices that others are making. And the greater the wealth or power gap between us and those whose choices we‚Äôre told about, the stronger our desire to want the same.
 
If you‚Äôre a parent, though, FOMO gets amplified exponentially. Because, now, you‚Äôre compensating for the choices you never got while trying to ensure your child more than makes up for it. FOYKMO >>> FOMO. (YK = Your Kid.)
 
This is why education is such a powerful, emotional and, if well run, profitable business. Parents will spare no expense when it comes to their kids' education.
 
WhiteHat Jr, a two-year-old company that teaches kids how to code, was distilled FOMO. Which is why Byju‚Äôs, India‚Äôs leading edtech company and its only decacorn (worth $10 billion or more), swooped in to buy WhiteHat Jr for $300 million in cash last week even while the startup was looking to raise $50 million in venture funding.
 
After reading Sumanth‚Äôs story today analysing WhiteHat Jr, I‚Äôm honestly in awe of the sheer cleverness of their business model, marketing strategy, and execution.
 
Three million students, 5,000 teachers and $150 million in an annual ‚Äúrun rate‚Äù in just two years is next-level stuff. Especially if you don‚Äôt even have to hire teachers, because WhiteHat Jr is a two-sided platform that pays teachers Rs 275 ($3.7) per hour while charging students Rs 600 ($8) per hour.
 
What about developing curriculum? Most of its course content is not proprietary either. Its lessons are sourced directly from material already created by others like Blockly or Google‚Äôs ‚ÄúCode with Google‚Äù.
 
That leaves it to just create a tremendously well-orchestrated FOYKMO engine which convinces parents that coding will be the new lingua franca for the future. Wouldn‚Äôt they want their kid to be ‚ÄúWolf Gupta‚Äù?
 
Who is Wolf Gupta, you may ask? Please read Sumanth‚Äôs story, is what I‚Äôd answer: https://the-ken.com/story/byjus-300-million-acquisition-whitehat-jr/ (15-minute read)

*Space Exploration Technologies Corp.*, t/a SpaceX, is an American aerospace manufacturer and space transportation services company headquartered in Hawthorne, California. It was founded in 2002 by Elon Musk with the goal of reducing space transportation costs to enable the colonization of Mars. SpaceX designs, manufactures and launches advanced rockets and spacecraft.

It has gained worldwide attention for a series of historic milestones. It is the only private company capable of returning a spacecraft from low-Earth orbit, and in 2012 their Dragon spacecraft became the first commercial spacecraft to deliver cargo to and from the International Space Station.

Cutting-edge digital & data provisions that go far beyond the EU-Japan deal. These will enable free flow of data whilst maintaining high standards of protection for personal data. We have also committed to uphold the principles of net neutrality, as well as introducing a ban on data localisation, which will prevent British businesses from having the extra cost of setting up servers in Japan. This will help UK fintech firms operating in Japan - like Revolut and Transferwise - to innovate and grow.
Improved market access for UK financial services ‚Äì including greater transparency and streamlined application processes for UK firms seeking licences to operate in Japan. The deal creates an annual dialogue between Her Majesty‚Äôs Treasury, UK financial regulators, and the Japanese FSA that will explore ways to further reduce regulatory friction - something that would be impossible were the UK still in the EU. Financial services are our biggest export to Japan, accounting for 28% of all UK exports.

9/17/20, 20:09 - Vikas Business Phone: Asset tokenization is a term that is fairly common in block-chain lingua franca. Up until now, it was used to tokenize real estate or other pre-existing illiquid assets. 
To the best of our comprehension, the article talks about exploring the possibility of financial engineering in asset tokenization. 

As financial ecosystems evolved, they liquidized money that was otherwise stuck in real-estate and loans, etc. The author believes that this evolution can be achieved in asset tokenization as well; that a chain of events beyond initial asset creation and purchase can be achieved.

For instance, blockchain technology could give investors the ability to self-assemble bespoke investment products dynamically, specifying the assets, and creating tranches or other attributes best suited for their specific needs.
However, this transformation also requires a deep understanding of the types of investors that would buy tokenized assets.

It also requires a deep understanding of the types of investors that would buy tokenized assets. Investors are quite varied, from large to mid-sized institutions, mutual funds, pension funds, (multi) family offices, registered investment advisors, ultra-high net worth investors, and retail investors. Improving asset liquidity requires opening access to an asset to a broader spectrum of investors. The considerable potential that blockchain can bring to real asset financial products is best served first to institutional investors where they have the expertise to evaluate these new vehicles and co-create new financial products with this technology. As these new products mature, then retail investors would have more information to act on. 

Digitization platform companies need to have a deep understanding and appreciation of securities regulations and take a collaborative approach with regulators to address their concerns to create financial innovation successfully. Only a few digital securities fintech companies are beginning to show a critical understanding of the regulatory landscape, have asset expertise, and complementary proficiency across the investor ecosystem. 

The good news is that such ecosystems, although in their preliminary stage are here (examples are cited towards the end of the article) and financial engineering in asset tokenization, comparable in sofistication to traditional ecosystems, has become a real, achievable milestone.

9/18/20, 18:16 - Forum of Industry and Academic Knowledge Sharing: *FINAL ANSWER TO FIAKS QUEST 93*

_The former president and CEO of Bank Leumi,_
_the answer to today's quiz is:_

*Rakefet Russak-Aminoach (IsraelüáÆüá±)*

Rakefet Russak-Aminoach started her career as the personal assistant to Bank Leumi‚Äôs then-deputy CEO Galia Maor (later known as Israel‚Äôs Iron Lady of banking). 

In May 2012, she took up job of Leumi's CEO and endured a rough first few years. In 2015, 2016 and 2018, Russak-Aminoach was listed in Fortune's *100 Most Powerful Women in Business* list. She was ranked 43rd in the international list in 2018.

For Rakefet Russak-Aminoach, part of being a good leader is knowing when to leave. She says, no chief executive _"should sit in their chair for dozens of years."_ It was partly for that reason that she announced she was leaving Leumi in June 2019 and giving up her prominent role as one of the world's only female bank CEOs.

On Tuesday, Team8, a Tel Aviv- and New York-based venture group backed by Microsoft, Walmart, Barclays, and Moodys, announced that Russak-Aminoach will be one of the leaders of its new arm, Team8 Fintech.

9/20/20, 11:27 - Vikas Business Phone: *FIAKS Gen Z Talent Show 4.0*

_An undergraduate says the recent issue between *Vijay Shekhar Sharma and Google* reminds him of a public war between *Steve Jobs and Adobe*. He shares these insights from his latest read *Steve Jobs by Walter Isaacson*_ )

Jobs's vision that your computer could become your digital hub went back to a technology called *FireWire*,which Apple developed in the early 1990s.It was a high speed serial port that moved digital files such as video from one device to another.Japanese camcorder makers adopted it,and Jobs decided to include it on the updated versions of the iMac that came out in October 1999.He began to see that FireWire could be part of a system that moved video from cameras onto a computer, where it could be edited and distributed.

To make this work,the iMac needed to have great video editing software.So Jobs went to his old friends at Adobe,the digital graphics company,and asked them to make a new Mac version of Adobe Premiere,which was popular on Windows computers. *Adobe's executives stunned Jobs by flatly turning him down*.The Macintosh, they said,had too few users to make it worthwhile.Jobs was furious and felt betrayed. "I put Adobe on the map,and they screwed me,"he later claimed.Adobe made matters even worse when it also didn't write it's other popular programs,such as Photoshop,for the Mac OSX,even though the Macintosh was popular among designers and other creative people who used those applications.

*Jobs never forgave Adobe,and a decade later he got into a public war with the company by not permitting Adobe Flash to run on the iPad*.He took away a valuable lesson that reinforced his desire for end-to-end control of all key elements of a system:"My Primary insight when we were screwed by Adobe in 1999 was that *we shouldn't get into any business where we didn't control both the hardware and the software,otherwise we'd get our head handed to us*."

So starting in 1999 Apple began to produce application software for the Mac,with a focus on people at the intersection of art and technology.These included *Final Cut Pro*,for editing digital video; *iMovie*, which was a simpler consumer version; *iDVD*,for burning video or music onto a disc; *iPhoto*,to compete with Adobe Photoshop; *Garage-Band*, for creating and mixing music; *iTunes*,for managing your songs;and the *iTunes Store*,for buying songs.


_*Make In India* is all about nurturing the Gen Z talent and encouraging their *bootstrap ventures & ideas*_ üí°

_The world's *3 Worst Offenders for Plastic Pollution*, as of 2020, are as follows:_
(Figures in parenthesis indicate metric tonnes of plastic packaging produced annually)

*No.1*
Coca-Colaüá∫üá∏ (2.9 million)

*No.2*
Pepsicoüá∫üá∏ (2.3 million)

*No.3*
Nestl√©üá®üá≠ (1.7 million)


Since plastic production took off in 1950s, it has skyrocketed to 448 million tonnes by 2015. From this just 9% of all plastic has been recycled, while 12% has been incinerated and *79% has ended up in landfills or the natural environment.*

The Changing Markets Foundation has released a new report naming and shaming the world's worst plastic waste offenders. Entitled "*Talking Trash: The Corporate Playbook of False Solutions*", the report states that the companies involved are actively taking steps to obstruct and undermine legislative solutions aimed at tackling an unprecedented global plastic waste crisis. Industry tactics to *distract, delay and derail legislation* are being used by corporations and industry associations in countries around the world. 

Recommendations for companies in the report include "Commitment to meaningful measures that would lead to a significant reduction in single-use plastics and other single-use materials. These measures need to be specific, measurable, time-bound and independently verified, and should include support for reuse, redesign of products and effective recycling."

9/27/20, 15:23 - Vikas Business Phone: *FIAKS Gen Z Talent Show 5.0*

_An undergraduate shared these insights on BRAZIL üáßüá∑ from his latest read *Breakout Nations*_ )

When we say that *India* is an emerging market, it can either be the *next Brazil* or it can be the *next China*

Brazil is a country that has always been emerging. Each of Brazil's elected Presidents since 1980 came in with a different version of the same plan- _freeze prices and introduce a new currency_, something that happened *five times in a decade*. In 1994, the inflation in Brazil touched 2100% and Brazil ended this nightmare with the introduction of the 'Real'. However, Brazil has battled inflation ever since by maintaining high interest rates,which has attracted a surge of foreign money. This explains why the Brazilian Real is so expensive compared to most currencies, dampening it's exports.

Exports could have been used as an instrument of Brazil's growth as the market value of Brazil's state owned oil giant, *Petrobras* reached more than *$300B* in 2008. Interestingly,the total value of Turkey's stock market in the same year was less than $200B. 

The *starking similarities between India and Brazil* should concern the Indian govt as Brazil had offered the world's most generous welfare program- *Bolsa Familia Income Supports* until the Indian *MGNREGA* got that tag in 2005. 

_If you think *CXO title* is precondition to be a  thought leader then please start interacting with *Gen Z* as  they will surprise you with talent and depth. Lets encourage and start investing in  their *bootstrap ventures & ideas*_ üí°

The time of day or night you drive
The speed you drive at on different sorts of road
If you brake or accelerate sharply
If you take breaks on long journeys
Your motorway miles
Your total mileage
This information is then used to work out how safely you drive.

_*10 rules changing from tomorrow_*:-


_*From 1 October 2020, many rules are going to change_*, Motor vehicle rules, Ujjwala scheme, health insurance, credit and debit card rules are changing from tomorrow. *So it is important that you know about them in advance*. Let us know what is going to change from October 1.
1) *No physical verification of documents like Driving License and RC*
The tension of keeping a hard copy of documents like RC and driving license together while driving is going to end. Now you can drive a vehicle with only a valid soft copy of these documents attached to the vehicle.The Ministry of Road Transport and Highways has issued notification of various such amendments made in the Motor Vehicles Rules 1989, which will come into effect from October 1. In a step towards easing commuter convenience, the central government is set to digitise documents including maintenance of vehicles, driving licences and e-challans that will now be done through an information technology portal from 1 October 2020. *Drivers can maintain their vehicular documents on Central govt's online portal like Digi-locker or m-parivahan.*

2) *Mobile phones only for route navigation* :-
According to the amendments made in the Motor Vehicles Rules 1989 by the Ministry of Road Transport and Highways, _*you will now be able to use mobile for route navigation in such a manner that it shall not disturb the concentration_* of the driver while driving.

3) *LPG connection* will not be free
Under the marque Pradhan Mantri Ujjwala Yojana (PMUY), the process of getting a gas connection for free is ending on 30 September 2020. The Union cabinet had approved an extension till end September for availing free cooking gas cylinders under PMUY.

4) *5% tax will be levied on foreign fund transfer*
Any amount sent abroad to buy foreign tour packages, and every other foreign remittance made above ‚Çπ7 lakh, will attract a tax-collected-at source (TCS) beginning 1 October unless tax is already deducted at source (TDS) on that amount. While the tax on foreign tour packages will be 5% for any amount, for other foreign remittances the tax will kick in only for the amount spent above ‚Çπ7 lakh.

5) *Sweet sellers will need to display 'best before date*'
Sweet shops will now have to declare the 'best before date' of non-packaged or loose sweets available in their shop. Food Safety and Standards Authority of India (FSSAI) has directed the sweet shop owners to adhere to the protocol from 1 October.

6) *New health insurance rules to be implemented*
The changes in the health insurance cover have of course being introduced in the aftermath of Covid-19. The prices for premium health services will eventually rise. The new health insurance rules to be introduced post-Covid-19 inclusion will make 17 permanent illnesses outside the cover.

7) *Buying television sets can be expensive*
Open cell panels will attract 5% import duty from 1 October, with the government saying that a duty exemption expiring at the end of this month will not be extended . _As part of 'Atmanirbhar Bharat' the government is keen to expand domestic production capacity_ for open cell panels so that imports can be curbed. The one-year exemption given to the item expires today, 30 September.

8) *RBI‚Äôs new credit and debit card rules*
The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has issued new guidelines to secure debit and credit cards. These _changes will be effective from 1st October 2020_. According to the new guidelines, card *users will now be able to register opt-in or opt-out of services, spend limits, etc. for international transactions, online transactions as well as contactless card transactions*.

9) *FSSAI bans blending of mustard oil with any other cooking oil*
Food regulator FSSAI has banned blending of mustard oil with any other cooking oil with effect from October 1. In a letter to commissioner of food safety of all states and Union Territories, FSSAI said the "blending of mustard oil with any other edible oil in India has been prohibited with effect from October 1, 2020."

10) *New Tax Collected at Source (TCS) regime*
The Income Tax Department issued guidelines for applicability of TCS provision which requires an e-commerce operator to deduct 1 per cent tax on sale of goods and services. The new Tax Collected at Source (TCS) regime will come into effect from October 1 . The Finance Act, 2020 inserted a new section 194-O in the Income-tax Act 1961 which mandates that with effect from October 1, 2020, an e-commerce operator shall deduct income tax at the rate of 1 per cent of the gross amount of sale of goods or provision of service or both, facilitated through its digital or electronic facility or platform.

_*Partner of large VC/PE form on ‚ÄúIs VC legal Ponzi?‚Äù post says*_ 
Since this is a an informal yet serious forum, thought will put out my point of view here.
With no offense meant - i humbly *disagree* with the VC being considered legal Ponzi statement.  Tech has been a savior in this pandemic and definitely the way forward.  And the driver of the tech, innovation and development has been through VC investments.  of course, there are losses and high loss ratios but then its the power law that makes the model successful :)

_*Fintech Founders On the post ‚ÄúInsurance companies tracking your driving‚Äù*_

do they have black boxes in India now? for insurance.. its a box u fix on ur car, to monitor ur driving style..so, innsurance schemes with black box, will have lower premium...
isnt that what u meant when u said "track ur driving"?

*View 3*
Black box insurance (also known as telematics insurance) is having a small black box fitted to your car that is used to gather the following information:
The time of day or night you drive
The speed you drive at on different sorts of road
If you brake or accelerate sharply
If you take breaks on long journeys
Your motorway miles
Your total mileage
This information is then used to work out how safely you drive.
https://www.insurethebox.com/young-drivers-insurance

*View 5*
Some cos ask you to install a mobile app to track your driving. The app will track kms, driving speed, hard braking etc. Based on the driving habit it recalculates premium every month. 

If you drive well these tracking apps can be very beneficial. It does throw up the question of privacy because they track all your trips and over time this information could become valuable enough to be shared with advertisers. 

Just like with any other technology, there needs to be a strong governance framework on the usage of customer data.
If anyone has not seen the Social Dilemma - highly recommend it. Nothing new which us tech folks did not know but it is def a well produced documentary.

*Response*
ah. dint know they use mobile apps.. thats a more cost efficient method, but more reliant on the customer..

10/2/20, 15:56 - Vikas Business Phone: _Intellectual Speaks:FIAKS Community Experts on FIAKS *eBulletin 2.0*_

*View 11* CXO fintech 

Ideally Cooperative bank deposit should be more safe compared to Private or Foreign bank?. Regulators have given unconditional guarantee to private bank (eg YES Bank), please do all non- sense.. we are there to bail you out from tax payers money. Sad ! Sad !!

*View 9* CXO cooperative bank 

Look at branch opening in rural by RBL bank, DCB bank, IndusInd Bank, Federal bank, Yes bank, South Indian bank üòÇ

*View 5* CXO banker 

Foreign banks  cater to very high networth clients who may be keeping 50 lakhs average balance with them  of which only 5 lakhs is covered by insurance.  But smaller banks esp *co-op banks* will have large number of depositors keeping less than 5 lakhs and hence fully insured deposits.  Since the cap is at an account level only way to bring down the cost of insurance is by pushing up the ticket size of deposits.  We should consider that small banks are able to compete better thanks to the safety insurance cover offers.

*View 7*
Cost serving *non smartphone* users big. Insurance needs to be subsidised for cooperative banks and regulatory authorities should load that cost on Pvt and mnc banks. 
Instead of putting restrictions on cooperative bank.. Need to open newer opportunities and better support is expected for them. Isn‚Äôt it ?

10/4/20, 15:09 - Vikas Business Phone: *FIAKS Gen Z Talent Show 6.0*

_An undergraduate shared these insights from his latest read on *What India needs to do to be a successful economy*_

If we need to be a fair economic society, we need to leverage our *female labour force*. In terms of women participation, just 23% of working age Indian women participated in our labour force, second last to Saudi Arabia among G20 countries. It is also below Nepal, where roughly 80% of women work. Nearly 120m Indian women have atleast secondary education,but they do not participate in the workforce. *A major reason for them to not do so was unpaid care work*. This is the work of caring for children and elders, of managing a household. Indian women are responsible for 87% of unpaid care work, compared to 72% in China and 61% in the US respectively. In India,women perform 9.8 times as much care as men.If all of this unpaid work were valued and compensated in the same way as paid work, it would contribute to *$300bn* to India's economic output. Of the 12 crore educated Indian women, even if half of them entered the workforce,the share of total workers(men and women) with atleast a secondary education in the workforce would jump from 33% to 46%. *Their engagement would add $440B to India's GDP* .The childcare system of several countries providing affordable day care and paid leave offers some solutions for India. In Sweden,if parents share time off, they receive tax credits.Financial incentives, creative approaches to flexible work solutions, along with tax and pension credits more than doubled the amount of paternity leaves Swedish men took.Private care providers receive public funding only if they follow national quality guidelines.No household has to pay more than 3% of it's income as childcare fees, raising low-income families access to care. Single mothers do 16.5% more paid work as a result. Austria lowered the income tax on second earners to encourage women's participation in the workforce.In 2017, the U.K went a step further to correct gender bias by requiring a disclosure of pay gaps from large employers(250 or more employees). In the second year of it's implementation,44% of it's employers noted an improvement in the pay gap from the previous year. Most Nordic countries and Asian countries like Japan and South Korea strongly encourage working fathers to take time off, making it mandatory quite often.If India focussed on childcare alone,it could add up to four million new jobs in the care industry and help up to 10m additional women participate in the workforce. *Another example is Indonesia:a country where 50% of it's MSMEs are owned by women*. In India,this figure is lower than 14%. Digital platforms expand possibilities,allowing quick and low-cost access to global markets for smal-scale ventures.In Indonesia,the share of women owned MSMEs in e-commerce revenue is 35% compared with only 15% in offline buisnesses.


_If you think *CXO title* is precondition to be a  thought leader then please start interacting with *Gen Z* as  they will surprise you with talent and depth. Lets encourage and start investing in  their *bootstrap ventures & ideas*_ üí°

The PayTM app store - its not an app store. It lacks the many basic fundamental requirements in an app store.

*View 65*  _FIAKS Maven 2019 and 2020_

India‚Äôs own App Store... well a great idea whose time has come I guess. Though as others opine, this one is more a container app than an app store.

First, I don‚Äôt know if PayTM is planning to build a mobile OS. If it does, keeping the economics aside, that becomes the primary foundation for an app store ... I assume that isn‚Äôt the cause, for this note.

BTW: if it isn‚Äôt the case, an app will still need to be hosted on Google/ Apple stores! üôÑ

Next, for a true app store, there must be a developer environment that needs to be made available. It cannot be restricted to a payment related idea which may be built on this, but any foreseeable idea.

Then there must be an app submission/ verification workflow, a beta environment, and an appsec setup. The developer has to still operate within the boundaries of the platform.

The app then needs to be published‚Äîit should be a pull model, rather than >>all<< apps being visible in a menu/ grid layout.

And last but not the least, there must be a developer community, willing and excited to create new apps on the said platform.

There will be more pre-requisites, but this is what I could think of, for now.

10/9/20, 18:12 - Forum of Industry and Academic Knowledge Sharing: *FINAL ANSWER TO FIAKS QUEST 95*

Q1. The only vendor who had a Positive Annual Growth from Q2 2019 to Q2 2020
*Ans. Apple (25% Growth)*

Q2. The vendor with the Highest Market Share as of Q2 2020.
*Ans. Huawei, with a market share of 19.6%*

The source of the data is Canalys estimates (sell-in shipments), Smartphone Analysis, July 2020. *The global smartphone market plummeted 14% in Q2 2020, with Apple the only top vendor to grow.*

Apple defied expectations in Q2. Its new iPhone SE was critical in the quarter, accounting for around 28% of its global volume, while iPhone 11 remained a strong best-seller at nearly 40%. As well as the new iPhone SE, Apple is also demonstrating skills in new user acquisition. 

In addition, market share leadership rankings changed from Q2-2019 to Q2-2020 as Huawei toppled Samsung from the top position. It was also the clear market leader in China, taking 44% market share. Huawei shipped 55.8 million units, compared to Samsung‚Äôs 53.7 million in Q2 2020. Xiaomi came fourth, shipping 28.8 million units, which was down 10%, and Oppo reclaimed fifth place from Vivo, shipping 25.8 million units with a 16% decline.

As lockdowns ease, many countries allowed offline retail stores to reopen, but footfall remained low. Going forwards, vendors will need to switch channel focus at short notice, to adapt to second-wave outbreaks. In addition, geopolitical uncertainty also hangs over the global smartphone market.

10/12/20, 15:25 - Forum of Industry and Academic Knowledge Sharing: _FIAKS Bespoke_ *Neo Banking License: Do We Need Another Banking License Category?*

To spur innovation it makes sense to have a 2-tier license, one which is bank-sponsored and therefore ultimately the funds are held with and insured by a Tier1 bank. The second could be an independent license that carries more responsibility and therefore also allows more flexibility to the new entrants.

Regulatory authorities will find it difficult to issue a digital banking license. As the fresh license category may give advantage to digital banks over payments banks. There will be no takers for any license category with more restrictions compared to payments banks.

10/12/20, 22:11 - Vikas Business Phone: *Intellectual Speaks:FIAKS Community Experts on OTP SMS for FINANCIAL TXN*

*View 19* _start up founder_

Are Regulatory Authorities Banks, NPCI aware that SMS OTP is unsafe ? Are we putting customers to such a BIG risk by having Aadhar Auth services for opening bank accounts, fund transfer, Income tax returns filing basis these OTP‚Äôs ..what‚Äôs happening in this country ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

*View 14*.  _Doctorate in Law_

There will be soon a app just for OTP management.ü§£

*View 17* _Chief Digital Officer of an organisation which employee more than 5lakhs people_ 

The world has moved beyond OTPs long ago. NIST has been advising against SMS OTP for a long time (at least since 2017). Please note that colloquially "OTP" is understood as SMS OTP. Multiple other versions of OTP/challenge exist, e.g. Google (shows a challenge on device you are already logged in), Apple, Microsoft Authenticator and so on. 

*View 6* _Founder with Telco back ground_

*The transmission of an SMS in GSM network is not secure*

The SMS messaging has some extra security vulnerabilities due to its *store-and-forward feature*, and the problem of fake SMS that can be conducted via the Internet. When a user is roaming, the SMS content passes through different networks and perhaps the Internet that *exposes it to various vulnerabilities and attacks*. Another concern is arisen when an adversary gets access to the phone and reads the previous unprotected messages. To exploit the popularity of SMS as a serious business bearer protocol, it is necessary to enhance its functionalities to offer the secured transaction capability. Data confidentiality, integrity, authentication, and non-repudiation are the most important security services in the security criteria that should be taken into account in many secure applications. *However, such requirements are not provided by the traditional SMS messaging*.
10/12/20, 22:16 - Croma Maneesh Mittal Head e- Commerce NnR: This message was deleted
10/13/20, 00:05 - Remitr Sandeep Todi Co-founder NnC: Strangely enough some Canadian carriers / telco plans do not forward SMS when roaming outside the country. In such cases, OTP by sms becomes a bottleneck. We also have to keep in mind that SMS is the lowest common denominator and its readily accessible to all. On the contrary, using Google Authenticator or another software based OTP is not easy for non-tech people.

So, while the security of SMS can be suspect, there is a trade-off to using it when you consider reach of the SMS technology vs other technologies.

Reserve Bank of India: Enhancing Security of Card Transactions 
Effective October 1, 2020

New Cards
All new DR/CR cards issued by the banks will be only enabled for domestic transactions at ATMs and PoS terminals  
New cards issued by any bank from this month will need to comply with the regulation, so by default the cards will be in ‚ÄòOff‚Äô mode, and customers will need to activate the feature (for eComm purchases). This can be activated instantly/real-time via the bank app/website.

Existing Cardholders
Issuers may take a decision based on their risk perception, whether to disable the CNP(domestic & int‚Äôl) transactions, card present (int‚Äôl) transaction and contactless transaction rights. 
Treasury Feedback from HDFC & Citi - All existing cardholders will continue to have access to performing e-Comm transactions. By default, the banks have enabled eComm purchases as ‚ÄòOn‚Äô and the customer has a choice to turn it ‚ÄòOff‚Äô
All the DR/CR card users from now on are allowed to set up transaction limits.

Existing Inactive Cardholders
RBI has asked all the banks and card issuing companies to disable online payments for all those DR/CR cards which have never been used for online or contactless transactions in India or abroad. These consumers will have to proactively enable their cards to ‚Äúon‚Äù mode for eCommerce.
