The Top 3 Countries with the highest density of Robot Workers in the Manufacturing Industry, as of 2019, are:

*No.1*
Singapore üá∏üá¨(918)

*No.2*
South Korea üá∞üá∑(855)

*No.3*
Japan üáØüáµ(364)

*The Rankings from 4-10 are as follows:*
4. Germany üá©üá™(346)
5. Sweden üá∏üá™(277)
6. Denmark üá©üá∞(243)
7. Hong Kongüá≠üá∞ (242)
8. Chinese Taipei/ Taiwan üáπüáº(234)
9. United Statesüá∫üá∏ (228)
10. ItalyüáÆüáπ (212)

Data from the International Federation of Robotics reveals that the pace of industrial automation is accelerating across much of the developed world with 74 installed industrial robots per 10,000 employees globally in 2016. By 2020, that increased to 113 across the manufacturing sector. 

Manufacturing - which contributes about 20 per cent of Singapore's gross domestic product (GDP) and 14 per cent of total employment - is being impacted by new technologies, changes in global supply chains and consumer demands and  manufacturers are using robotics, to remain relevant.

In 2019, South Korea had 855 installed industrial robots per 10,000 employees. That is mainly due to the contiued installation of high volume robots in the electronics and electric sectors. Germany and Japan are renowned for their automotive industries and they have density levels of just around 350 per 10,000 workers. Interestingly, Japan is one of the main players in industrial robotics, accounting for over half of the global supply.

10/18/20, 17:47 - Vikas Business Phone: *FIAKS Gen Z Talent Show 6.0*

_An *undergraduate* shared these insights from his latest read on *What correlation between education & economic growth*_

One of the ways India can right the *talent mismatch* is by focusing on its secondary educated work force.These workers can become the technician, sales executive, customer service agent that will be needed as middle class expands. But that might not meet the aspirations of a college educated person.
According to the World Bank,the ‚ÄòAsian miracle‚Äô  that led South korea,Japan and Taiwan,among others,had more to do with investments in primary and secondary education than with investments in higher education.However,if these workers need to find jobs in their respective sectors,we need to strengthen our SMEs(Small and Medium Enterprises),as explained in a survey conducted by Tata Sons.This is something that is an efficient alternative to the definition of 'M'SMEs used by the government of India.FIAKS community member says according to TataSons,the Indian business landscape is characterized by a large number of micro-businessess,who optimistically call themselves ‚Äòentrepreneurs‚Äô. *These micro businesses,are just survival ventures,employing less than 10 people.If they had a chance,many of these ‚Äòentrepreneurs‚Äô would opt for staid,unglamorous jobs*.A survey conducted by Columbia University concluded that the average size of an *Indian firm in 2014 was just 2.24*,giving an indication of how many  educated workers would  remain unemployed. These firms employ over 70% of India's workforce working in *informal* private companies. The extent to which *formalised firms* are productive for an economy is also explained in another survey conducted by Columbia University which stated  that an Indian Manufacturing firm employing 50-200 employees is approximately four times as productive than the one that employees between five and fifty,because of their levels of formalization.These firms i.e five to fifty may relatively remain dormant to firms that are adept in technology, i.e 50-200 employees. A combination of three surveys conducted by Tata Sons,US Bureau of Labour Statistics (2014 data),OECD(2014 data) and the updated Economic Census of India concluded that the Micro firms(1 to 9 employees) employ 11% of the private sector employees in the US, 20% in Germany, 27% in Israel(70% for India), compared to *SMEs*(10 to 249 employees)that employed 36% of the private sector employees in the US,43% in Germany and 43% in Israel.

FAB Queries
‚ñ™Ô∏è *What is Primary education?* , the first stage traditionally found in formal education, beginning at about age 5 to 7 and ending at about age 11 to 13.

‚ñ™Ô∏è *What is Secondary education?*, the second stage traditionally found in formal education, beginning about age 11 to 13 and ending usually at age 15 to 18.

10/23/20, 18:05 - Forum of Industry and Academic Knowledge Sharing: *FINAL ANSWER TO FIAKS QUEST 97*

The 3 Most Impersonated Brands in Phishing Scams are:

*No.1* 
Google 

*No.2*
Amazon 

*No.3*
WhatsApp

Phishing is among the most common cyber-attacks, targeting both individuals and companies. According to Verizon‚Äôs 2019 Data Breach Investigations Report, roughly one third of successful data breaches involved phishing activity, and phishing was instrumental to 78 percent of cyber-espionage incidents and the installation of backdoors to networks.
In recent years, phishing mails have become a lot more sophisticated and some of them are really hard to distinguish from legitimate mails. In many cases, such attacks involve the attacker imitating a well-known company/brand, a practice commonly known as ‚Äúbrand phishing‚Äù. According to a recent report from Check Point Research, technology companies appear most often in fraudulent emails, with Google, Amazon and WhatsApp topping the list of most impersonated brands.
 
Email phishing exploits were the second most common type after web-based exploits, compared to Q1 where email was third.  The reason for this change may be the easing of global Covid-19 related restrictions, which have seen businesses re-opening and employees returning to work.

Turns out it is number 1 for Q3 2020, with DHL and Google taking the next 2 spots (as per this Checkpoint report).

are banks allowed to NOT accept inter-bank transfers, just because they meet their capital requirements? can bank NOT accept cheques from other banks?

in the short term, this sounds inconvenient to players who were hoping to dominate market with their might and hefty wallets, but in the long run, i personally feel this is a good move, for the end consumer.. which should be the focus..
10/25/20, 10:29 - Fintech Netpay Ajay Founder NnC: and definitely good move for fintech ecosystem, by large.. coz now even small startups will have access to the entire QR code network..

very much like the mandatory open-banking prerogative in the EU..
10/25/20, 10:30 - Fintech Netpay Ajay Founder NnC: open-banking or open-QR (in this case) will have no meaning, if the bigger players chose not to participate.. and stay proprietary.. so, why not! i can definitely think of more positives than negatives, with this move..

10/28/20, 22:27 - Vikas Business Phone: _Intellectual Speaks:FIAKS Community Experts on *Name and account number matching*_


*View 15* CXO Banker shares his experience of UK üá¨üáß 

He says From 31 March 2020, the UK‚Äôs six largest banking groups will start checking whether the name entered on a bank transfer matches the names of the recipient bank account. It is hoped the move will combat transfer scams and errors and make it less likely customers‚Äô money ends up in the wrong hands.

This is introduced to help customers avoid transfer fraud in which the victim is provided with the bank details of a fraudster rather than the person to whom they believed they were transferring money. Common examples of this kind of transfer fraud include:

‚ñ™Ô∏èthe victim has a legitimate invoice to pay, but the fraudster intervenes (perhaps by intercepting emails or hacking an email account) to convince the victim to redirect the payment to an account they control.
‚ñ™Ô∏èinvoices being tampered with so that the account details for payment are switched to the fraudster‚Äôs account. This kind of fraud might be perpetrated from within a business by an employee with responsibility for raising/processing invoices.
‚ñ™Ô∏èa fraudster masquerades as a CEO or other senior company official and persuades an employee to transfer money to the fraudster‚Äôs bank account
a fraudster impersonating a trusted organisation, such as HMRC, the victim‚Äôs bank, or their utility company, and telling the victim a payment is owed.

10/29/20, 13:49 - Fintech Easy2lend Riaz Maniyar NnR: Jack Ma has made headlines today for raising more than $34 billion in the World‚Äôs largest IPO in history for his company, Ant Group - which was only launched 6 years ago.

Trading starts next week on the Shanghai and Hong Kong Stock Exchanges, at a value of over $300 billion. What has made Ant Financial such a big deal, and why does this mark the end of big banks and the finance industry as we know it?

Traditional banks are set up as an expensive middle man, where banks charge us to store our money, give us less interest than our savings lose in inflation, and then loan the same money back to us at much higher interest, while also using that money to invest and keep all the profits.

Ant doesn‚Äôt work like a traditional bank. It‚Äôs an 'Amazon for money' that makes it easier - not more difficult - for us to earn, exchange and invest our money at a fraction of the cost, in a fraction of the time.

That‚Äôs how Ant has become the world‚Äôs highest-valued fintech company and the world‚Äôs largest digital payments platform with over one billion users and 80 million merchants today.

Beginning as Alipay in 2004 as a Chinese version of PayPal, Jack Ma connected his payment platform with over 200 Chinese Banks by 2010. While PayPal has stayed as a payment platform, Jack had other ideas, giving users multiple ways to make money with their money:

> Yu‚Äôebao, Ant‚Äôs investment platform allows users to invest their money directly in money markets, and is already the world‚Äôs largest money market fund.

> Zhima Credit, Ants‚Äô credit score system, gives users a way to get financing, lending, buy a house or car immediately based on their payment record, with over 10 million users getting credit even if other banks have given them a poor credit score.

> MYbank, Ants‚Äô online bank, can approve a loan in minutes. It has already given out over 20 million loans to companies that otherwise could not easily get them.

> Ant Fortune, Ant‚Äôs investment supermarket, gives financial institutions a place to reach all Ant users and to educate and serve them with their investment products.

> Xiang Hu Bao, Ant‚Äôs mutual protection plan, gives users a way to secure their own insurance by all paying in to a central fund that then pays out in the case of critical illness. Again, with no extra fees are charged to those who take part. Over 50 million signed up in the first six month.

> Antchain, Ant‚Äôs Blockchain-based platform, gives users a trusted network to transfer assets, including music, videos, articles, contracts and other IP with digital copyright certifications.

In 2014, Jack turned Alipay into Ant Group with a vision of turning Ant into the Amazon of money. And that is what it has become. 

While traditional banks give a poor customer experience and make it difficult to set up a new account, to make an international transfer or choose the right investments, Ant works like Amazon, where the customer experience is the main focus, at the fastest speed and the lowest price.

This is summed up in Ant‚Äôs ‚Äúthree-one-zero‚Äù process - three minutes to apply, one second to get a credit decision, and zero people involved in the decision.

In the same way that Amazon has led to any retailer who is not completely customer-focused going out of business, Ant is the new paradigm that will lead to every bank that is not completely customer-focused also going out of business in the coming decade.

As Bill Gates says, ‚ÄúThe world needs banking but it does not need banks.‚Äù

Banking is one industry that will be massively disrupted in the coming digital decade. Other industries ready for disruption include education, healthcare, energy, automotive, transportation, every industry still relying on middlemen, and government itself.

Which wave are you riding?

10/30/20, 16:47 - Forum of Industry and Academic Knowledge Sharing: *Hint 2*

10/30/20, 17:26 - Forum of Industry and Academic Knowledge Sharing: *Hint 3*

10/30/20, 18:06 - Forum of Industry and Academic Knowledge Sharing: *FINAL ANSWER TO FIAKS QUEST 98*

The First and Oldest Central Bank in the World is:
*Sveriges Riksbank*

In 1668, Sweden's parliament decided to found Riksens St√§nders Bank (the Estates of the Realm Bank), which in 1867 received the name Sveriges Riksbank. The Riksbank is thus the world's oldest central bank.
The estates of the realm were the four classes of society. They represented the nobility, the clergy, the burghers  and the peasants in the Riksdag of the Estates until the reform  of 1866 when the system was replaced by a bicameral legislature.

Sweden is a small open economy that is highly affected by events in the global economy. By participating in international work, the Riksbank strives to the best of its ability to contribute to price stability and financial stability in the global economy. 

The Riksbank regularly participates in around 180 international committees and working groups. The Riksbank also has direct contacts with central banks in other countries to discuss issues of joint interest or to provide technical assistance (advice to central banks in emerging economies).

11/1/20, 17:33 - Vikas Business Phone: *FIAKS Gen Z Talent Show 8.0*

_An *undergraduate* shared these insights from his latest read on *Swami Vivekananda*_

The universe must be resolved into it's causes;the sun,moon,stars and earth,the body and mind,and everything in this universe must return to their finer causes, disappear,be destroyed as it were.But they will live in the causes as fine forms. Out of these fine forms they will emerge again as new earths,suns,moons and stars. Swami Vivekananda compares this philosophy to the real world. The seed comes out of the tree,but it does not immediately become a tree. It has a period of very fine unmanifested action. While working for some time beneath the soil,the seed breaks into pieces, degenerates as it were, and *regeneration comes out of that degeneration*.The same way,the whole universe has to work for a period unseen and unmanifested (called chaos),and out of that comes a new projection. This process is *known as a 'Kalpa' in Sanskrit*. We see that these finer forms develop slowly and gradually become grosser. These fine forms become grosser until they reach their limit,and later they go back further,becoming finer again. This process in modern times is known as evolution. However,every *evolution is preceeded by an involution*.The seed is the father of the tree,but another tree was itself the father of the seed.The seed is the fine form out of which the big tree comes,and another big tree was the form which is involved in that seed.Similarly,the whole of the universe was present in the fine cosmic universe.Everything exists through eternity, and will exist through eternity.The evolutionist will tell you that your idea of God is wrong.God is intelligent,but that intelligence develops much later on in the course of evolution. It is in man and the animals that we find intelligence, but millions of years have passed in this world before this intelligence came.In other words, the tree comes out of the seed,goes back to the seed;the *beginning and the end are the same*. 

It is unsurprising that such a man (Swami Vivekananda) could impress the likes of *Nikola Tesla and Leo Tolstoy*. However, it should be noted that this concept of the "big crunch" and the idea of a *multiverse* were expressed by Swami Vivekananda in 1895,a decade earlier than the much-celebrated set of papers of *Albert Einstein*,heralding a new age in Physics.

11/2/20, 18:59 - +91 90233 89243: Major issue with this is there is no standard way of generating this password and it becomes almost useless if you forget it.
11/2/20, 19:11 - Nearex Arun Tanksali CTO NnR: The password adds a bit of inconvenience, but I think it is useful to keep. 11/2/20, 20:31 - Fintech DBS Amit Jadhav Digibank Sgd NnC: There can be 2 type of bank account statements.
1. Download Open directly from ib / mb, via View eStmt section
2. Send email to cust account.

If at any point of time, you can able to access your ib/mb - view statement, then why bank is sending as pwd protected pdf. It's easy for cust to login and download when-you-need basis. Depending on regulatory requirements, banks can store these pdf / generate on-the-fly pdf up 7 to 10 yrs data.
This will reduce so-called 'complicated' pwd maintenance logic of dob/personal questions/cif/name letters +dob. Many info security teams from banks accept pwd-less in-app pdf and okay to send email about eStmt readiness, rather than pwd protected pdf.
If cust view that all his stmt available in app, he never opens pwd protected pdf. Practically Performance cannot be seen any issue here. 

Risk - if bank is sending my stmt to you and pwd is to save that scenario, then bank need solid estmt mgmt system. (good developers and smart info sec guy's.) üòâ

11/2/20, 22:19 - Vikas Business Phone: _Intellectual Speaks:FIAKS Community Experts on *WHY ACCOUNT STATEMENT REQUIRE PASSWORD*_.

*View 37* Founder FIAKS Maven 2019 and 2020 

Why even send a statement?
Login & download when you need ü§∑üèª‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è. Any unnecessary communication from bank is a potential phishing / fraud risk, these days!. What if a hacker sent you a email looking like a statement from bank? You would happily open the attachment & it could be a trojan or virus! ü§¶üèª‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è. *In this age of phishing & fraud by cloning, cloning an email is the easiest to do*!

*View 61* FIAKS Maven 2019 & 2020 

In general, this appears to be a genuine concern of a normal account holder who does not have transactions in his account which deserve privacy. But, there are several situations in which the account holder may need to prevent anyone other than himself from seeing the transactions. This can be true for Retired Pensioners who live with children or relatives that are keen to know his financial status and transactions. This could be true for a wife or husband undergoing a marital strife... There could be many such reasons for individual account holders. For corporate and business accounts the reasons are more obvious. Prior to digital era these were veritable problems as a pass book or a physical statement was almost impossible to secure. Physical files in businesses and corporates also presented unsurmountable  challenges. In a digital environment this has become easier to manage. So, enhancing privacy leveraging technology is a good step forward.
However, the manner of implementing passwords in estatements by  banks leaves a lot to be desired
1. The key to the password is embedded in the same mail as the one that carries it. In such a scenario, snoopers familiar with the person's personal data like name and date of birth (most prevalent data which is used in some combination or other) is easy to break... In a shared or networked  device ( many people still do not use a dedicated device) it still carries a risk of being compromised. So, there is a need to look into methods by which the password is implemented in such situations

Password is a Must
Security of Password too is a Must

*View 2* _Serial entrepreneur and founder of several large fintech & FIAKS Maven 2020 shared an article that helps in understanding the issue and possible repercussions globally following_ 

A. Regulators have long aimed to *curb the fast-growing online lending industry* to prevent systematic risks to the vast financial sector

B. Beijing has become more *uncomfortable with banks heavily using micro-lenders or third-party technology platforms* like Ant for underwriting consumer loans, amid fears of rising defaults and deteriorating asset quality in a pandemic-hit economy.

C. China's central bank and banking regulator separately published draft micro-lending rules on Monday which seek to increase the bar for micro-lenders to be able to provide online loans directly to consumers or jointly with banks, while limiting the amount they can lend.

The draft, open for public feedback until Dec. 2, *requires small online lenders to provide at least 30% of any loan they fund jointly with banks*, which is widely considered to be a key rule that will hurt the profitability of Ant's current business model.

11/6/20, 11:14 - Forum of Industry and Academic Knowledge Sharing: _FIAKS Bespoke_: *Does The Farm Bill Actually Encourage Free Market Concept?*
The new bills will take away the exclusivity, which APMC‚Äôs currently enjoy over the purchase of farmers‚Äô produce. There is an established chain of market intermediaries, who are terribly unhappy with this. 

Small and marginal farmers are those who get affected due to unfavorable prices in the market. Now they will have an opportunity to sell where the price is favorable. But can he take it to that favorable market? Can he afford transportation? If he can afford, will it be a favorable price for his quantity of produce? He still will sell to the aggregator (middleman) who will sell it in a favorable market. It doesn‚Äôt seem there will be many benefits to the intended section of farmers. _*The bills can serve its purpose only if the ‚Äúfree market concept‚Äù is practiced in reality.*_

11/12/20, 11:19 - Forum of Industry and Academic Knowledge Sharing: _FIAKS Bespoke_ *Usage-Based-Insurance: Doesn‚Äôt It Raise Privacy Concerns?*

UBI is referred to as Telematics insurance in the car insurance industry. Through the use of telematics technology, a plug-in device or a pre-installed network in a vehicle or through mobile applications, a range of data such as how the vehicle is driven, the speed of driving, distance, fuel consumption, harsh braking, etc is collected is sent to the insurance company which keeps a track of such data and offers you additional discounts based on how good you drive.

If you drive well these tracking apps can be very beneficial. *However, it does throw up the question of privacy* because they track all your trips, and overtime this information could become valuable enough to be shared with advertisers.

11/12/20, 20:51 - Vikas Business Phone: _Intellectuals speaks: FIAKS Community thought leader recommending *strategy for 80% of customer who are today become more of  an expense and hardly contributing to any revenues*_ 


*View 59* former CEO of very large organisation says

The ratio will remain the same if you lose 80%. That will reduce the income. Think how you can increase the ratio to 25:75 and so on. There are many instances of businesses doing this kind of analysis and losing entire business. Don't lose customers. Think how to make them consume more of your products. For example a small change in price can increase turnover and increase the ratio

I had done an analysis of  a shop which had cotton and silk. Silk gave maximum profit but then people came to buy cotton but bought silk. When the shop moved to complete silk the customer foot print crashed and silk did not sell. Silk could not compete with other silk shops who had more varities

11/12/20, 22:15 - Vikas Business Phone: _Intellectuals speaks: FIAKS Community thought leader recommending *strategy for 80% of customer who become more of an expense and hardly making any revenues*_ 


*View 71* CXO who is part of leadership team of large MNC shares his experience 


 The Pareto's rule applies to almost all businesses. We all would live to cherry pick our customers. But unfortunately, that will never be the case when dealing with the masses. This is where Customer Value Management comes in, on how we can continue to retain our High Value customers, while trying to enhance the revenues coming from Low and Mid Value customers. Growing revenues from LVC and MVC customers is always tough and almost always entails more costs in the short term. The principle usually is Much More for More, i.e for a little extra fee, you give away disproportionately higher value of service for a certain period of time.. hoping that the customers will get used to / habituated to the service ir see value in it and subscribe to it permanently. The other way and a slightly risky one too is to *identify your bottom 10% customers  and to gradually downgrade the Quality of service being offered to them. Many service providers may even go to an extent of actually giving them a poorer user experience, hoping that they leave*..
Both the approaches work and may be chosen based on ones risk appetite and principles of business.

11/20/20, 18:05 - Forum of Industry and Academic Knowledge Sharing: *FINAL ANSWER TO FIAKS QUEST 100*

The Top 3 Private Pandemic Relief Donors, as of April 2020, are:

*No.1*
Jack Dorseyüá∫üá≤ ($1 billion)

*No.2*
Bill & Melinda Gates üá∫üá≤ ($255 million)

*No.3*
Azim Premji üáÆüá≥ ($132 million)

As reported by Forbes, Jack Dorsey has emerged as the most generous giver so far, after announcing on April 7 that he was moving $1 billion of his Square stock into an LLC to support COVID-19 relief efforts and other causes. It‚Äôs unclear how much of this $1 billion will go toward the coronavirus pandemic (so far he has given out about $5 million combined to four organizations), but even if it ends up being just 20% of his pledge, he will still have far outspent his peers. 

The second-largest pledge comes from Bill Gates and his wife Melinda, whose foundation has committed $305 million, much of it to be spent on vaccines, treatment and diagnostic development.

Indian tech magnate Azim Premji comes in third, planning to give $132 million to humanitarian aid and health interventions to curb the spread of COVID-19.

*View 82* _Mr Vijay Shekhar Sharma founder Paytm and FIAKS Maven_

Too many point of failures in a system. These too many points are created to build open and multi party participation. So a system which is mash of diverse scope by multiple parties and multiple tech providers is defiantly going to have some outages. I believe it requires even *bigger commitment by key players* to keep system up and running. I think it is one of and shouldn‚Äôt be looked at as grave issue. Every bank / company wants to serve their customers so they will protect and build next level of scale too. Cheers,

*View 87*  _CTO of large fund house and FIAKS Maven says_
*On Amex*
 Amex is using a separate network / switch and is not through MASTERCARD/VISA While the POS could be the same, connectivity is separate. Don‚Äôt have the details of what exactly went wrong, but it would not have impacted the Amex network/switch

11/25/20, 21:22 - Vikas Business Phone: Intellectual Speaks: FIAKS Community Thought Leader present contrarian view *ENTRY OF CORPORATE INTO BANKING*

*View (3 out 84) - CXO*
( _We recommends this CXO to be consider for CEO in the new venture or as a Board Member by Top *Founders* in the community. FIAKS will try to set-up an informal meeting with you if FIAKS Maven agrees_)

He says 

I have a contrarian view on this. 
We can extol the virtue of a model only if it has been reasonably successful in the past.  *Banks sans corporate promoters have not in any way reduced the risk of collusion between banks and corporates either in India or anywhere else*.  If anything, it has worsened the collusion by making banks vulnerable to the charms of not one but several corporates.  When quite a few banks have died and many more have gone through near death experience despite  some of them being owned by Govt itself (the anti thesis of corporate ), why assume corporates promoting banks would spell further disaster. 

Today banking across the world has become *oligopolistic mainly because of huge  entry barriers*. This has in turn resulted in too big to fail banks  regulatory forbearance and bailouts. Further such *large banks tend to favor large corporations at the cost  of SMEs*  and other marginal borrowers. *What we really need is an ecosystem comprising  banks small enough to fail but big enough to be competitive*. We can have a few very large global banks that are tightly regulated and ring fenced from retail depositors, but a larger body of our financial system should comprise mid-sized banks that do vanilla commercial banking.  An efficient way to develop such eco system is by giving out more licences to strong corporate promoters with known track-record instead of shutting them out from banking scene (I prefer licence on auction at periodic intervals, a la telecom). Along with freeing up the licencing the regulator should shift their objective  from bank protection to banking system and depositor protection. This can be achieved by stipulating higher liquidity ratio for retail deposits and making retail deposits senior to other forms of debt and allowing orderly demise of inefficient players. There should be a well defined rule triggered process for takeover of weaker banks by an apex entity (IBA) for orderly wind down without inconveniencing retail depositors. Locking the stadium gate and not allowing new players to enter is lazy refereeing. It makes those who are inside the stadium complacent if not arrogant. Bank shares are so abnormally high priced to book value only because of this 'inside stadium' advantage.

Further the current entry barriers in banking has given rise to a parallel financial sector of shadow banks and NBFCs that ultimately dip into banks' coffers for fuelling their growth.  creating additional systemic risks. It is better to transform these nbfcs to non retail banks instead of allowing them to take down a bank on their way down. 

To sum up it will be advisable to bifurcate bank as follows 
1. Large Financial conglomerates.
2. Full scale commercial banks (vanilla commercial  banking entities)

3. Retail Banks (only retail deposits and retail +SME loans) 
4. Non retail commercial Banks (where no retail deposits are taken). and liquidity prescriptions and regulatory oversight should ease proportionately from 1 to 4.   
Proper ring fencing of banks in different rungs should be ensured to avoid cross  contamination of systemic risks from higher rung to lower rung banks. Ownership will become least of our worries if we can develop a graded financial system with rule based regulations that allows risk takers to flourish or fail while insulating risk averse depositors from such failures

12/3/20, 22:44 - Vikas Business Phone: _Intellectual Speaks:FIAKS Community Experts on *Regulatory Audit of Switching off production server for one month and making all financial institutions work on DR*_

*View 35* CXO FIAKS Maven 2020 

Theoretically stimulating questions.

However, it must be remembered that banks typically have hundreds of systems, and only a handful can be seen as critical (e.g. customer facing), primarily basis their CIA (Confidentiality, Integrity, Availability) requirements.

DR can be created at 100% capacity of the primary, or a smaller percentage thereof depending on the CIA values. A 100% DR for 100% systems is generally infeasible, both economically and operationally.

Next, regardless of the criticality, systems are interwoven. Which means that the theoretical-single-switch being pulled down in the DC will (theoretically) shift the identified critical systems to DR, for most part, but other systems (without a DR) would also go down with them. Needless to say, since the systems that are now in DR may lose connectivity to (some of) their dependant/ interwoven systems due to power down, it would be a bit difficult to predict the overall behaviour of the systems.

A better approach is to create an Active-Active setup between two sites ‚Äî that too has some other set of challenges ... 

(that‚Äôs for another time üòå)

The countries with the largest decrease in their CO2 emissions, as of August 31, are:

*No.1*
Spainüá™üá∏ (-17.2%)

*No.2*
IndiaüáÆüá≥ (-13.4%)

*No.3*
U.S.A.üá∫üá∏ (-12.9%)

The largest contributor to this drop is the reduction in ground transport use - down 17 percent on 2019 and accounting for roughly half of the overall change. Of the individual countries for which data has been published, Spain has shown the largest decrease compared to 2019, as of August 31.

This data was calculated/estimated by Carbon Monitor. With businesses, manufacturing and transport picking, we as corporations and citizens should ensure that environment consciousness sticks with us beyond the pandemic and becomes a lifestyle.

*Why UPI QR can‚Äôt debit wallet Bespoke* Misguided digitalisation 

View 7: Founder 

_If Credit/ debit card, Net Banking, UPI, IMPS or ATM card can all be used to top up your wallet.So don't see how and why we can't also use UPI QR to debit from the   wallet. But then, can one  use NET BANKING to debit your wallet_  ü§î.

*View 11* CXO Banker 
_Well, technically why not! After all currency in digital format can stay in a bank account or in a wallet, it‚Äôs all the same.But one situation I envisage is that this might then be used as a back channel for wallet-to-wallet transfer. This isn‚Äôt permitted I guess, since wallets are semi-kyc instruments still.Other than that, it‚Äôs like transmission media are generally independent of the content type they want to transmit! üòå_

*India trending news : HOW UJJIVAN MODEL IS DIFFERENT FROM BC?*

*View 2*: CXO Banker 

BC has to be fed with cash. Kiranas rotate their own cash.  So cash management becomes. Simpler, efficient and scalable. Just to compare further with the ATM.  Zero capital costs.  You amortize the capital cost and pay off the kiranas. Still you will be breaking even faster

Google hosts it's own authoritative DNS, while it hosts recursive DNS 8.8.8.8 to internet users like opendns and comod offer recursive dns...have to see at what scale this *DDOS* happened to take down Google services across continents and respective datacenters...GEO BALANCED CLUSTER Going Down, *A BIG Lesson for our startups and INDIAN BANKS too*.

*FAB Query* WHAT IS DDOS ?
 _In a distributed denial-of-service attack (DDoS attack), the incoming traffic flooding the victim originates from many different sources. This effectively makes it impossible to stop the attack simply by blocking a single source_.

_A DoS or DDoS attack is analogous to a group of people crowding the entry door of a shop, making it hard for legitimate customers to enter, thus disrupting trade._

12/18/20, 18:02 - Forum of Industry and Academic Knowledge Sharing: *FINAL ANSWER TO FIAKS QUEST 104*

The 3 Countries Losing the Most to Tax Abuse are:

*No.1*
IrelandüáÆüá™ (22.6%)

*No.2*
Colombiaüá®üá¥ (18.20%)

*No.3*
Singaporeüá∏üá¨ (10.73%)

*Countries ranking 4th-10th are:*

4. Pakistanüáµüá∞ (9.30%)
5. Angolaüá¶üá¥ (7.36%)
6. Mexico üá≤üáΩ(6.45%)
7. Egypt üá™üá¨(6.14%)
8. Netherlands üá≥üá±(5.43%)
9. United Kingdomüá¨üáß (5.35%)
10. Philippinesüáµüá≠ (4.73%)

(The parentheses indicate the estimated annual losses due to tax abuse as a share of total tax revenue collected.)

When looking at these losses compared to a country's total tax revenue receipts, Ireland, while also a significant facilitator itself, is impacted to one of the highest degrees in the world. The estimated losses incurred via corporate tax abuse and private tax evasion are equivalent to 22 percent of its total annual tax revenue each year. 

As Dr Dereje Alemayehu, poignantly stated: ‚ÄúThe State of Tax Justice 2020 captures global inequality in soberingly stark numbers. Lower income countries lose more than half what they spend on public health every year to tax havens ‚Äì *that‚Äôs enough to cover the annual salaries of nearly 18 million nurses every year*."

The Tax Justice Network is the source of the aforementioned data.

12/28/20, 23:26 - Vikas Business Phone: _Intellectual Speaks:FIAKS Community Experts on *How is banks, payment companies de-risking SENIOR CITIZENS from FRAUD due to digitisation*_

*View 61* FIAKS Maven 2019&2020

In the current case the money got transferred digitally. If banks or the service provider, can't find the money trail, then they have to pay. *If the recipient money can't find the actual person to whom the account belongs means that KYC is not proper*. Bank should be asked to pay the money + penalize bank for not doing the kyc properly. Get the aadhaar details and blacklist the aadhaar card. *Wherever the aadhaar card is being used catch hold of the person*. Collect the money from that person and credit back the funds to the recipient bank. Until this is done, *no bank will be serious in finding out the details of the person who has done the fraud as banks are not losing money*, and they can put the blame on the senior citizen.

This is a place where TRAI has to pitch in. Currently *True caller gets the details from other persons phone numbers and provides the details to the call receiver on the number from where the person is receiving the call. Is it not possible for TRAI to do this in this digital world ? It is willingness to help the general public that matters*.

I was standing in a branch. One  staff was having a list and was calling each person in the list and was asking "sir, loan chahiye kya". Why RBI or TRAI is not banning this ? Instead have a common website. Ask the person to provide the details in the website. Whichever bank is interested in providing the loan, let them provide the loan. Competition increases and customer benefits.

Vast and growing amounts of Chinese economic activity are now handled through digital apps that have become part of the fabric of life in modern China, led by Tencent's WeChat Pay and its rival Alipay, run by Alibaba spin-off Ant Group. Together they dominate the huge Chinese online payments industry, typified by shoppers scanning QR codes to make purchases rather than use physical cash, which has become old-fashioned in China.
In November the government called for a nationwide push to "strengthen the ability of the elderly" to use digital tech, urging communities to hold training sessions and developers to create elderly-friendly apps. This has become even more imperative in the era of the coronavirus, which emerged in the Chinese city of Wuhan.

1/11/21, 18:58 - Nearex Arun Tanksali CTO NnR: Q1 : This seems a rather dangerous mentality. "Allow" implies some kind of License Raj, and we know how that works.  In any case, different flavors of license already exist - with different constraints and permissions. There is a class - the App provider - which fortunately does not require anything. The system is designed to protect consumers from a disaster. Neither Google nor Whatsapp nor PhonePe hold end user funds. If they all disappear tomorrow, there won't be any problem greater than that of inconvenience. We will back to the age a scant 5 years ago when convenience of the kind today can only be dreamt of. I think the approach should be to invite even more people - bring on competition and let the consumer choose.

Q2 : Why should anyone other than Facebook or Jio be privy to this answer?

Q3 : They were already having a tough time. Verifone and Ingenico went through a change of hands mostly due to the arrival of the commoditized Chinese POS and well before either the Pandemic or app based payments. But they also evolve ... at least the more innovative ones.
1/11/21, 19:31 - Transact Services Muthukrishnan GM Sales Ref Jack NnR: Question-3...there is a time when barcode machines, then hypercom, Lipman n Verifone pstn terminals were ruling the pos industry, then came ingenico pstn terminals, after that Verifone introduced gprs terminals,market dynamics changed thereafter, ingenico too introduced gprs, then the android terminals been introduced by Chinese companies...but then ingenico and Verifone still rule with their gprs/pstn terminals updating regularly with the market requirement of UPI n bharat qr within Pos terminals.they do support all samsung pay, amazon pay etc.
As long as physical card is available in the market, the requirement of POS terminals will be there, chinese terminals are only fancy devices but no self life, which is evident in the market...
  When physical card issuance get stopped, pos terminals requirement will slowly goes down..
Otherwise UPI/Qr payments will be only an alternative mode of payment, one will not replace another, probably market share may change according to the user experience and geographies.....

1/11/21, 23:06 - Remitr Sandeep Todi Co-founder NnC: Ans 1
Big tech entering payments - protectionism in any form will only stifle innovation. The question needs to reframed to not single out big tech but to ask how can every payment provider have a level playing field and participate in the public goods that are being built. Ultimately, these platforms are only adding a convenience layer to the existing system and not replacing it. 

Yes, if regulator started allowing them to function like a wallet for p2p payments then it‚Äôs a different ballgame. But these platforms are payment processing tech and not wallets. 

Nothing stops Whatspp from launching a WhatsApp Card in the future and linking it with WhatsApp Pay. That then is a different product and will have it‚Äôs own set of regulations.

1/11/21, 23:26 - Vikas Business Phone: _Intellectual Speaks:FIAKS Community Experts *Sponsor bank arrangement with tech companies & Future of POS Manufacturing companies*_

*View 39* _Future of POS_
POS Machines will survive either until alternate interaction modes like QR Code/NFC etc takes full precedence or till people reduce the usage of Chip based Credit/Debit Cards.They surely survive for next 5 to 8 years by when, NFC will surely happen in every phone, and UPI multiplying it's presence in India & abroad when the duo will make card & pos machine combination less lucrative (with acquirer banks charging around Rs.500/month for pos machine), and while NFC cards might still be used with NFC enabled mobile phone (in the hands of merchants), *POS Machine is sure to go off thereafter gradually*.

*View 4* _Tech giants_ 
Market concentration is key. Not  whether foreign firms should have unfettered power in market. 
Has anyone done a *CR4 + Hefindahl-Hirschman index calculation* to measure if there is unnatural  concentration of market power in few firm? With that one can make a case for ensuring  fair and competitive  market space in Payments...both domestic and overseas players.


*FAB Query* What is CR4 + hefidahl-hirschman ? 

The Herfindahl index (also known as Herfindahl‚ÄìHirschman Index, HHI, or sometimes HHI-score) is a measure of the size of firms in relation to the industry and an indicator of the amount of competition among them. Named after economists Orris C. Herfindahl and Albert O. Hirschman, it is an economic concept widely applied in competition law, antitrustand also technology management.

Also, according to sources, Piramal being a local firm would have helped it find favour from the DHFL creditors.
The CoC will now formally meet again and DHFL administrator will declare the result.

The bidding war for DHFL has been going on for a while with Piramal Group and Oaktree Capital leading the race in the final round.¬†Piramal Enterprises, a diversified Indian conglomerate, and American asset management company Oaktree have both made bids in the range of Rs 37,000-38,000 crore. 

The cash components are also almost identical, at about Rs 17,000 crore each.

Throughout the bidding process, Piramals had contested strongly that its bid has an upper hand over Okatree¬†for a range of reasons.

Besides the financial aspects, creditors also evaluated the non-financial part of the bids such as regulatory compliance, company track records and future action plan etc, according to officials who are in the know.
Piramal has a clear edge over Oaktree in the race,¬†Moneycontrol¬†had¬†reported earlier.

DHFL collapsed under the weight of a severe liquidity crunch after the collapse of Infrastructure Leasing & Financial Services (IL&FS) in late 2018 and couldn't recover from the low point subsequently.

Adding to its woes, investigations were launched against the Wadhawans on various charges relating to financial irregularities and unholy nexus with the underworld in relation to certain real estate transactions. Subsequently, DHFL was pushed to the National Company Law Tribunal (NCLT) in December 2019. Since then, the creditors to the company have been attempting for a resolution.

*DHFL owes around Rs 91,000 crore to its creditors.¬†State Bank of India¬†is the biggest creditor to DHFL with an exposure of around Rs 10,000 crore. Other lenders include Bank of India, Canara Bank, NHB, Union Bank of India, Syndicate Bank, and Bank of Baroda*

1/17/21, 21:38 - Vikas Business Phone: _Intellectual Speaks:FIAKS Maven 2019 & 2020 on *ICICI bank outage* says_

Whether it is icici , axis or hdfc or kotak or  IndusInd, everyone will go through some technology failures at one point or another.  As far as the current problems of icici and hdfc are concerned, I think the exponential growth of electronic payments after  *IMPS and UPI is the root cause*.. This is a case of hardware and middleware not keeping pace with the software evolution. *Several banks and nbfcs have started doing penny drop txns periodically to check the validity of account numbers* . This itself will push up txns volumes greatly though these as essentially dummy txns. 

*Policy Advocacy recommendations by FIAKS Maven*

I believe it is time to segregate very low value payments (below 1000) from other txns and route them through a parallel payment rail.

1/17/21, 23:02 - Vikas Business Phone: _Intellectual Speaks:FIAKS Community Experts blames it *cancerous unplanned digitalisation growth* for all such outages_

*View 76* : CXO Banker
There is not that much revenue for banks with UPI or IMPS, but still they have to maintain a good infra considering the huge volume of transactions. This eats up the infra of other payment systems also. There should be a limit on number of UPI transactions per day for each customer. If we see in many public sector banks, opening and closing balance of many accounts will be less than 100, there will be many transactions through out the day. Bank can't charge these customers also as these are as per government norms not to be charged. *There should be some regulation to be brought in*. Most of the banks are bleeding on these transactions. Until there is a governance on these transactions, it will be difficult.
